HEADLINE: Pataki's Losses Mount Amid Refinancing Fight 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 25 

 BODY:
A bruising summer-long bout that could be titled State vs. City is continuing in the court's Appellate Division this week, with Gov. George E. Pataki fighting as hard as ever to block a deal that could save the city $500 million a year.
 With a failed lower court decision behind him, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and state legislative leaders locked in alliance against him, and a broad swath of public opinion siding with the city, Mr. Pataki is nonetheless sticking to his fiscal cause. 
 Last week, a day after his loss in State Supreme Court in the opening round of the legal fight, he restated his opposition to the Legislature's plan to allow the city to refinance $2.5 billion worth of debt left over from the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, with the state paying back the new long-term loan. 
"Thirty years from now, people not yet born will be paying taxes to pay off an operating debt incurred in 1975," Mr. Pataki said at an appearance on Long Island last week. "That's not right, and not only is it not right, we think it was done in a way that is illegal. We're going to fight for the taxpayers."
His aides and allies say the governor believes that the cost of the refinancing plan, $5.1 billion over 30 years, is too much for state taxpayers to pay, and that there are other ways to help the city. 
Lisa Dewald Stoll, his communications director, portrays him as a fiscally conservative Republican who cares more about principles than political wins and losses.
"New Yorkers know and trust Governor Pataki to do the right thing," Ms. Stoll said. "It's not about politics, it's about good government, and in the end good government is good politics."
Yet many political strategists and politicians say Mr. Pataki is also in it for the victory, something that has been lacking from his resume in the last few months.
The governor, they say, is still reeling from a setback in the spring, when Republicans and Democrats in the Legislature teamed up to steamroll him on the budget. The legislators also joined forces with Mr. Bloomberg to push through the bill giving the city fiscal relief.
Earlier this year, the Republican mayor won both in substance and on the public relations front as Mr. Pataki tried a last-minute maneuver to influence the split between the state and city of federal aid for antiterrorism preparedness.
This summer, one of Mr. Pataki's major public policy initiatives, reforming the state's drug sentencing laws, ended with a string of embarrassing headlines over the role of a hip-hip impresario whom he invited to join the legislative talks.
At least for the moment, Mr. Bloomberg seems to have gained the upper hand in the court fight over the bond refinancing plan. 
At the same time, the governor's energy policies have been called into question by Democrats, who have used the blackout as an excuse to hold hearings on deregulation.
The setbacks are all the more startling because Mr. Pataki was once such a dominating part of state politics that there was little he could not get through the Legislature or force to come to fruition through administrative acts.
One reason for Mr. Pataki's glide through his first two terms was the wave of economic prosperity he was riding. That changed this year, as the state faced an $11.5 billion budget gap, and can look forward to an estimated gap of $5.3 billion next year. 
Despite Mr. Pataki's insistence that the gap should be closed without raising taxes -- a position that many legislators saw as his bid to tack back to the conservative wing of his party -- the Legislature passed a budget that raised taxes and kept cuts to a minimum, and offered the bond deal to the city. It then overrode Mr. Pataki's vetoes of the bills.
Hank Sheinkopf, a Democratic political consultant, said Mr. Pataki was known as a smart, crafty and clever politician. But he said the state's precarious fiscal situation continued to pose a big risk for Mr. Pataki, even as he casts himself as "defender of the pocketbook."
"Should the economy really take on a resurgence, the debt problem will start to disintegrate over time, he'll look like he's more in control, more of a winner, and he'll go out as a winner," Mr. Sheinkopf said. "But if the state's fiscal crisis and the city's fiscal crisis continue, and the economy doesn't pick up, it's hard to foresee a circumstance under which he walks out with tremendous favorables, as defined by the voters."
Supporters and opponents alike say Mr. Pataki is a natural political powerhouse in a state where the gubernatorial office comes with much intrinsic muscle. He has repeatedly won landslides for a Republican, a rare feat in a Democratic state, and is said to be most dangerous when he is underestimated.
"I feel like what I'm doing is I'm having a conversation where somebody is saying to me, 'Hey, it looks like this year Barry Bonds is only going to hit 50 home runs, what do you think is wrong with him?' " a Republican strategist close to the governor said last week.
But third terms can be difficult for governors if the economy is sour, said Mario M. Cuomo, who lost to Mr. Pataki after serving three terms. At the same time, Mr. Pataki has lost some of his longtime senior aides to the private sector, among them his chief counsel, James M. McGuire, and his communications director, Michael McKeon.
Many people on both sides of the political aisle have wondered if the loss of these and other strategists has led to some political missteps on the governor's part -- for example, entering the fray over funding for antiterrorism efforts too late to make a difference, and generating unnecessary ill will over a water filtration plant in the Bronx by trying late in the game to dictate terms of the deal to the city. 
Others point out that Mr. Pataki vetoed the deal to refinance the city bonds in May, but waited until August to block it through the obscure Local Government Assistance Corporation, which he controls.
"Best guess is he is trying to somehow portray to somebody, somewhere, that he is trying to do the responsible thing against those bad guys, those legislators, those big city mayors," one legislative official said. The official added, "I don't know if he needs a win or he just needs to show he's standing up, standing up for principle here, fight the good fight, even if he loses."
Mr. Cuomo said Mr. Pataki's fights with the mayor and Legislature may have left some city residents with the impression that the governor was reluctant to help them in meaningful ways. Nonetheless, Mr. Cuomo said, Mr. Pataki seems to be in pretty good political standing, considering the state's fiscal circumstances.
Indeed, if history is a guide, Mr. Pataki will be able to deflect much of the criticism now plaguing him. And, in recent weeks, he seems to be working hard at that, traveling the state, campaign style, and doling out fiscal goodies to communities in distress. Yesterday he was in Mount Vernon, announcing grants for housing.
The Republican strategist close to Mr. Pataki said most of the issues making headlines today would either be forgotten or deemed too arcane for the average voter to understand or care about in 2006, the end of his third term.
Mr. Pataki's national image is still in good shape, the strategist said, pointing out that in his view, Mr. Pataki has weathered budget problems better than other governors, notably Gray Davis of California.
"If the political fight were to erupt, and I've got Pataki, I feel like I am going to win," the strategist said. "I still got hands to go beat somebody up with Pataki. He's a great political instrument still. He's a strong guy. He could still win a fight."

HEADLINE: Tangled Up in Blue As Wild Berries Outgrow Demand 

BYLINE:  By NORMAN VANAMEE

DATELINE: MILBRIDGE, Me. 

 BODY:
"WE made blueberry gel nuggets and tried putting them into bagels, but they liquefied in the toaster." Ed Flanagan, president and chief executive of Jasper Wyman & Son, was having lunch in the backroom of the Red Barn Restaurant and reminiscing over past sales schemes. "Then we tried making blueberry candies, but chickened out when we realized we'd be going up against the big confectioners," he declared, taking a swig of blueberry juice. "Have you heard that the University of Maine is looking into adding blueberries to hamburgers," he said somewhat hopefully. "All it takes is one good idea." 
 If ever an industry needed a eureka moment, it is the wild-blueberry business. After two decades of technological breakthroughs, growers in Maine and Canada have suddenly found themselves with an excess of fruit. Bumper harvests in 2000 and 2001 sent wholesale prices through the floor. Last year Maine growers received 25 cents a pound for their fruit, a 17-year low. Companies like Wyman, plus hundreds of small family-run operations across this rugged section of northeastern Maine, have been scrambling ever since to find new customers for their fragile crop. 
 Wild blueberries are smaller and noticeably tastier cousins of the marble-size behemoths grown throughout the country and sold in grocery stores. It is difficult to describe their flavor because no two handfuls taste exactly the same. Unlike cultivated blueberries, a field of the wild crop contains dozens of slightly different plant varieties, called clones, which produce distinctly shaped and flavored berries. Part of the fun is noticing how one batch is impossibly sweet, the next tart and spicy.
Long before settlers arrived, American Indians migrated here to pick the fruit for food and medicine. In the 1800's, local fish canners like Jasper Wyman canned the berries and shipped them around the country. Now international agricultural corporations have moved in, bringing modern farming techniques and mechanical harvesters. 
The delicate, thin-skinned crop doesn't transport well when fresh. The harvest is only four weeks long, and unless the fruit is brought in perfectly dry and meticulously sorted, the tiny berries begin to bruise and become slimy after only a few days in a box. Fresh berries can be found at roadside stands throughout Maine and occasionally in stores in the Northeast, but most are frozen, canned or dried and sold to grocery stores and companies like Sara Lee for pie fillings and muffin and pancake mixes. (Weather permitting, Whole Foods in New York City will stock fresh berries through the first week of September.)
For years, blueberry farmers took a laissez-faire approach to growing. The plants seed themselves and farmers burned the fields every few years to kill weeds and insects and to prune the hardy plants back to their roots. In the last few decades, farming has become more active. "Nowadays, we irrigate, fertilize, spray, mow, pollinate and burn," said Darrell Newell, manager of the Northeastern Blueberry Company, an 1,800-acre farm owned by the Passamaquoddy tribe of Maine. "With all the things we do to them, it's a miracle anything grows here at all." 
But grow they do. Maine's output has tripled in three decades to a yield of 65 million pounds a year. Canadian growers have seen similar increases. 
"It's the age-old story," Mr. Flanagan said. "When something gets going good, farmers can grow things a lot faster than they can grow demand." Around 70 percent of Wyman's berries are sold to the ingredient industry, but Mr. Flanagan is working hard to woo new customers. With a recent study from Tufts University showing blueberries are high in antioxidants, the company is marketing them as a health food. The company has created a new line of juices and a resealable bag to make frozen berries easy to snack. All its blueberry products now have the tagline: No. 1 Antioxidant Fruit. 
Some companies have decided the new marketing is not enough and are trimming costs by using mechanical harvesters. Until recently, all harvesting was done by hand. In an area with limited economic opportunities, blueberry picking provides essential seasonal employment. It is also tremendously hard. Laborers spend the day stooped over ankle-high bushes pulling metal rakes through tangled branches. The teeth are close enough to catch the berries, but it takes a careful teasing movement to get them off without breaking their skin. Temperatures can climb into the 90's, and the air is often abuzz with mosquitoes. Still, rakers are passionate about the work.
The Passamaquoddy, who bought Northeastern Blueberry in 1980 with money the tribe won in a land settlement with the state of Maine, have vowed never to use mechanical harvesters. "Picking blueberries is part of our heritage," Mr. Newell said. 
"It gets into your blood when you're young," Allison Bernard Jr., 37, a member of the Micmac tribe from Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, declared. Standing with his son, Ashton, 13, Mr. Bernard created a yard-wide swath through the blue fields with a huge harvesting tool he had welded out of two rakes. Mr. Bernard and the 100-member crew he organized, mostly from tribe members, work from dawn to dusk and spend nights at one of Northeastern's campgrounds. "It's really a social thing," he said. "An opportunity to spend time with other people from the nation." 
But local interest has waned, and now many of Wyman's rakers are migrant laborers from Mexico and Honduras. 
That's a shame, said Dell Emerson, 68, of Columbia Falls, the owner of a small farm called Wild Wescogus Blueberries and manager of the University of Maine's blueberry research station. "When I was a child," Mr. Emerson said, "we'd all go up and spend the month camping out on the barrens," where the fruit grow. "It was really fun."
Like Ed Flanagan at Wyman, Mr. Emerson has been thinking of ways to sell blueberries. From a 25-foot-tall dome structure on U.S. 1, called Wild Blueberry Land, Mr. Emerson and his wife, Marie, sell fresh blueberries and all manner of concoctions, including pleasingly tart blueberry vinegar and blueberry wine jelly with a hefty boozy aroma and subtle bite. The word eureka comes to mind.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A DELICATE CROP -- In Maine, growers of wild blueberries like Darrell Newell, above, are struggling to find markets for their juicy, small but hard-to-ship berries, top. (Photo by York Photo)

HEADLINE: The Price of Not Keeping the Peace 

BYLINE:  By Arthur Hertzberg; Arthur Hertzberg, visiting professor of the humanities at New York University, is author of the forthcoming "The Fate of Zionism."

 BODY:
The cycle of violence that is once again gripping the Middle East presents the United States with another setback in its role as regional peace broker. Never has it become more clear that diplomacy alone cannot secure a workable truce between the Israelis and Palestinians. No resolution of the conflict is possible unless the United States pressures the two parties to make concessions that they have refused for decades to make. But what tools can Washington use? What if angry combatants on both sides decide that it is in their interests to continue to fight?
 The United States does have the means to impose its will, but we must put limits on what we should and should not do. Our government should not put troops on the ground to hound those who send suicide bombers into Israel, or to dismantle Jewish settlements in the West Bank. We would be playing the unsuccessful role of the British in the 1930's and 1940's as the conflict between the Jews and the Palestinians became ever bloodier. Yet, peace plans, of which President Bush's road map is the latest example, can only work if the power of the United States is behind them; otherwise they are merely part of the ongoing theater of the peace process. 
 The most effective way to force a reduction of the violence on both sides is to take punitive economic measures. The United States finances about $4 billion a year, on average, of Israel's national budget. The continuing effort to defend, support and increase settlements in the West Bank and Gaza costs at least $1 billion a year. The money spent annually in directly subsidizing the existing settlements was estimated in 2001 at $400 million.
An American government that was resolved to stop expansion of the settlements would not need to keep sending the secretary of state to Jerusalem to repeat that we really mean what we say. We could prove it by deducting the total cost of the settlements each year from the United States' annual allocation to Israel. To show that we were not being unfeelingly mean, the United States should add that we would hold $1 billion a year in escrow to help those settlers who would peacefully move back into Israel's pre-1967 borders.
No doubt there would be an outcry among some supporters of Israel, especially the ultranationalists, whose goal is to realize their vision of the "undivided land of Israel." But an American government that had the courage to force the end of settlement activity would find far greater support among Jews both in Israel and in the United States than many people in Washington imagine.
Much of this support is because of the pressing matter of demographics in the "undivided land of Israel." Between the Mediterranean and the Jordan River, the total population is now more than 40 percent Arab. Since the Arab birthrate is far higher than the Jewish (by a ratio of more than two to one), there will be an Arab majority in at most 20 years. At that point, Israel will effectively be a binational state. It will have to make a fateful choice between being a democracy that will empower the Arab majority to dominate its government or to subject the Palestinian Arabs to a rule resembling apartheid in South Africa.
The hard-liners in Israel and their supporters abroad avoid this prospect by talking about the "transfer" of population or of making life so difficult that the Palestinians would choose to leave. This is nonsense. Life has been difficult for the Palestinians for several decades, but they have not gone away in large numbers. 
The mainstream in Israel and in the Jewish Diaspora will be grateful to America for saving Israel from itself. The United States government must act with comparable tough love toward the Palestinians. No Israeli government, whichever party might constitute it, can put up with the defiance of the Palestinian militants who keep reiterating that their ultimate aim is to push the Jews into the sea. 
Yet the United States cannot replace Israel in the day-to-day battle with the enemies of peace. We cannot police the territories, for that task might become endless. What American influence can achieve is to dry up the financial and military support of the Palestinian war-makers. A good first step came on Friday, when President Bush ordered the Treasury Department to block the assets of the leaders of the militant Palestinian group Hamas and the charities that officials say help finance it. The group had claimed responsibility for a bus bomb a few days before that killed 21 people in Jerusalem.
But the United States can do more. It is within our power to insist that other countries -- both our allies and enemies -- freeze the financial accounts of militant groups and to demand that they also cease supplying the most violent Palestinian factions with weapons. 
If this does not work, there is no choice but to cut off all but the most basic humanitarian help that the United States, along with many other nations, is giving to the Palestinians. It will surely be an unpopular move, as we are certain to hear statements of compassion from those speaking out in the cause of human rights. But Israelis, too, have the right to ride in a bus or go to a cafe without endangering their lives. 
In the end, the anger at these tough measures will fade. The Palestinians will be left with their real problem: how to find work and living wages in a region that is economically depressed. And the two sides will have a common cause, to find ways of helping each other wage peace.
The United States must act now to disarm each side of the nasty things that they can do to each other. We must end the threat of the settlements to a Palestinian state of the future. The Palestinian militants must be forced to stop threatening the lives of Israelis, wherever they may be. A grand settlement is not in sight, but the United States can lead both parties to a more livable, untidy accommodation.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET-- New Jersey; 
As Factory Jobs Vanish, There's Value in Buildings

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
Nearly a third of New Jersey's manufacturing jobs have disappeared since 1990, leaving thousands in need of jobs and numerous old factory buildings in search of new uses if they are to be productive again.
 Many were simply torn down and replaced. "It mostly doesn't pay to try to convert old manufacturing buildings," said Stanley B. Danzig, a broker of industrial space for Cushman & Wakefield. Mr. Danzig cited a former plant in Cranbury, N.J., that he tried to market for a year as suitable for retrofitting as a warehouse and distribution center. 
 "It turned out its greatest value was for the land -- knockdown and redevelopment," said Mr. Danzig, who eventually brokered a pending sale to a company that plans to build new warehouse buildings on the site. 
There is a niche in making a research and development lab out of a candy factory or a textile warehouse out of a plant where submarine engines had been built. Mindy Lissner, a CB Richard Ellis broker, engineered two such deals in the last year, and about 20 "adaptive reuse" transactions in the last two years. 
During that time, the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University reported, there was a continued "severe, absolute and relative decline" of the role of manufacturing in the state's economy. Manufacturing accounted for slightly more than 9 percent of jobs in 2002, and 8.8 percent at midyear 2003. 
"New Jersey real estate is valuable regardless," Ms. Lissner said. "Any sort of company looking for a cheaper alternative can find possibilities with these tired, worn old buildings."
She and other brokers acknowledged that the loss of jobs hurts both the workers involved and the general economy. "The worst thing about marketing," Ms. Lissner said, "is you go into these buildings to assess their value while people are still working -- and you feel like the Grim Reaper. I remember walking around the General Dynamics building in Woodbridge, where there were 800 people working at one time, and everyone looks at you like, 'What's going on?' "
Ms. Lissner is part of a special properties group within CB Richard Ellis, which she described as "brokers around the country that concentrate on selling large manufacturing buildings in exurban areas -- which basically means the middle of nowhere." New Jersey is different, she said, because the population density is so great and the industrial market so busy. The average price of industrial real estate in the state is $35 to $40 a square foot, Ms. Lissner said, while in states like Georgia, Tennessee and Nebraska, it is $8 to $12. 
But the challenges and opportunities can seem similar: A 428,000-square-foot factory in Canton, Ga., where refrigerators were made, was recently sold to investors, who added loading docks and turned the building into a distribution center. The million-square-foot Electrolux plant in Edison, N.J., where air-conditioners have long been assembled, is not yet fully shut but is under contract for sale to the AMB Property Corporation, which plans to turn it into a distribution center.
Often, major renovations are needed, another broker, Jonathan M. Glick of Sheldon Gross Realty, indicated. He mentioned the purchase of a former steel manufacturing plant in North Brunswick, N.J., that was divided for warehouse space now used by seven companies.
"The cost of transformation had to be pretty high, but it was worth it," Mr. Glick said. Companies that locate in rehabilitated factories may not get all the latest bells and whistles of warehouse design, he said, but "they don't have to rely on some truck stuck on the Cross-Bronx Expressway for 10 hours to get their goods delivered, either."
Ms. Lissner said that one company's throwaway building can be another's castle. "For users out of Brooklyn and Staten Island who may be working on the sixth floor of a loft building, with the truck always double-parked out on the street," she said, to get a free-standing building "is a dream come true." She cited the conversion into a textile warehouse of a 398,000-square-foot building in Woodbridge where submarine engines were once manufactured as part of the Electric Boat division of General Dynamics. 
The former Hershey Foods plant in New Brunswick, where Chuckles, Jujubes and Gummi Bears were once made, had only 14-foot ceilings, and was broken up into many small rooms, Ms. Lissner said. It was purchased by a generic-drug maker, Ohm Laboratories, a unit of Ranbaxy Laboratories of India, to be lab and office space, and required considerable renovation. "But it works for them," she said, "and the building is still working. I call that a happy ending."

COMPANY: CUSHMAN & WAKEFIELD INC (58%); CBRE GROUP INC (58%); GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP (52%)

HEADLINE: Japan Is Spending Heavily to Pursue a Weak-Yen Policy 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The Japanese government is defying the logic of the foreign exchange market by keeping the yen from rising sharply in value against the dollar.
 The dollar has had a lot going against it this year, including strong doubts about the strength of the economic recovery, the lowest interest rates in 45 years and the war in Iraq and its aftermath. But while these concerns helped send the euro and other major currencies much higher against the dollar, the yen has not even left the launching pad. 
 By spending trillions of yen to buy dollars in the foreign exchange market, Japan has limited the yen's rise against the dollar this year to no more than 2.3 percent, while the euro has jumped as much as 13.5 percent. The yen is now up just 1.3 percent against the dollar while the euro is up 3.8 percent, almost three times as much. 
Japan's success in keeping the yen from gaining significant strength against the dollar -- and other currencies -- is helping the country's economy rebound by keeping its exports more competitive abroad. But, at the same time, it is a drag on American economic growth and is making it more difficult for the United States to reduce its troublesome current account deficit, which is now over $500 billion.
While Japan is one of the world's major industrial economies, the government's effort to manage the value of its currency is more reminiscent of a developing economy like China, which pegs its currency to the value of the dollar.
"The yen is a one-sided floating currency," said David Gilmore, a partner in Foreign Exchange Analytics. "It can only float lower."
C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said a former top Japanese finance official had told him that without the government's intervention, the exchange rate would be around 105 yen to the dollar, which would make the yen almost 12 percent stronger against the dollar than the current rate of 117.26.
What makes Japan's success all that more surprising, according to foreign exchange traders and analysts, is that speculators and others in the currency market usually make it impossible for governments to manage a free-floating currency over an extended period unless it is backed with changes in economic policy.
Britain was defeated by speculators in such an effort in 1992, when George Soros, the legendary hedge fund operator, was said to have made $1 billion from trades involving the pound. The currency crisis of 1997 was aggravated by speculators betting that countries like Thailand would not be able to continue to manage their currencies' value.
In addition, a recent surge in the Japanese stock market, where the Nikkei 225 index is up 36 percent since the end of April, is attracting foreign investors, whose purchases of yen should strengthen the currency.
But Japan has been successful by being aggressive, intervening in the market on 34 days through the end of June, the latest daily data available, and spending almost 9 trillion yen to buy approximately $75 billion, effectively stalling the rise of the yen and the fall of the dollar. (Another 179 billion yen was used to buy euros.)
This persistent intervention, which through July is only 1.4 trillion yen short of the 10.4 trillion yen worth of interventions over the previous three years, has basically scared off the hedge funds and other speculators who would be betting now on a rise in the yen and a fall in the dollar, just as they have bet this year on a rise in the euro.
"It has caught people off guard and people are just staying away," said one top foreign exchange executive about speculating on the yen. Officials in the Ministry of Finance in Japan, he added, "have sent deliberate messages to us to tell our hedge fund clients and proprietary trading desks not to speculate on the yen."
Japan's success is also based on the acquiescence of the Bush administration, which has not complained publicly about the negative effect of a weaker-than-should-be yen on American car and other manufacturers. If the yen strengthened, it would make Japanese exports more expensive here and, therefore, less competitive.
Rick Wagoner, the chairman of General Motors, has not been reticent, however. In a May speech, he referred to the difficulty of competing with Japanese companies "due to active intervention to keep the Japanese yen weak, versus the U.S. dollar."
As part of an effort to assuage governors and manufacturers who say that Chinese imports are undermining American business and costing jobs, the administration is pressing China to let its currency, the yuan, rise in value against the dollar. Because it is now pegged to the dollar it moves with the dollar and keeps its competitive advantage. A stronger yuan would cut into that advantage.
In last week's announcement of Treasury Secretary John W. Snow's visit to Japan and China next week, the Treasury Department said that "exchange rate issues" would be discussed during the visit to Bejing. But there was no mention of exchange rate issues in the description of the agenda for the meeting in Tokyo.
When asked about the statement yesterday, Tony Fratto, a Treasury spokesman, said, "Currency issues will be discussed in Japan, as well."
In an interview Monday, John Taylor, under secretary of the Treasury for international affairs, told Reuters that "there's no reason why recovery in Japan, in the sense of a sustainable rate of growth in the 2 to 3 percent area, should have any particular effect on the yen."
Referring to this comment, David Puth, global head of foreign exchange at J. P. Morgan, said, "It is apparent that the United States is reasonably comfortable with Japan's actions and is appropriately sensitive to the fragility of the Japanese recovery."
Mr. Gilmore of Foreign Exchange Analytics also said there was "some complicity here from the Bush administration" because the huge reserves of dollars the Japanese have built up during the intervention have been used to buy billions in Treasury securities; that has helped to slow the recent surge in interest rates here as the economic outlook improved. Other analysts said that Japan's support of the war in Iraq was also a reason for the lack of a response from the Bush administration.
But while Treasury officials have not complained directly so far, Mr. Snow has said that exchange rates should be set by the market. Analysts said this turn of phrase meant that the administration would accept a weaker dollar over all, and that it would like the Japanese to allow the yen to find its own value.
Another reason for the success, said Larry Kantor, the global head of market strategy at Barclays Capital, is that it is easier for a central bank to weaken its currency -- or keep it from getting much stronger -- than to push a falling currency higher.
In Japan's case, the Bank of Japan can use an essentially unlimited supply of yen to buy dollars, limiting the yen's climb. But to make the yen stronger, Japan would have to use its dollar reserves to buy yen. Although Japan's foreign currency reserves are formidable, they have a limit and that makes a strengthening much harder to accomplish.

But Japan has restrained the rise of its currency by spending nearly 9 trillion yen to buy dollars in the foreign exchange market. HEADLINE: Need Milk? Expect a Bigger Bite 

BYLINE:  By DAISY HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
For Rafael Martinez, it is bad enough that the price of milk will go up 47 cents per gallon on Monday. But worse, the increase will arrive the same week he has to buy notebooks, sneakers and pencils for his two children going back to school in Washington Heights.
 "Right now, my expenses are triple," Mr. Martinez said from behind the counter of Mas Grocery, the bodega he manages on the corner of 115th Street and Second Avenue. 
 In New York City, Long Island and the lower Hudson Valley, the price for a gallon of milk will increase on Monday to $3.16 from $2.69. In the rest of New York, the price will jump to $2.94 a gallon from $2.47.
"It is one of the highest month-to-month increases" in the past two years, said Jessica Chittenden, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, which monitors retail milk prices to prevent price-gouging. 
The price of milk is determined by how much the federal government decides farmers should be paid for producing it, based on supply and demand, Ms. Chittenden said. Milk has remained relatively cheap for the past 18 months at $2.69 a gallon, a price reminiscent of the 60's and 70's.
Prices initially went that low because of a cold, wet spring in 2000, said Larry Salathe, a senior economist at the United States Department of Agriculture. Dairy cows produced less milk. Farmers began earning more for their milk and started to overproduce.
Then came 9/11, and a drop in demand because fewer people were eating out, said Peter Fredericks, a chief economist based in Albany with the United States Department of Agriculture. Farmers, left with lower prices for their milk, began producing less, resulting in the latest price increases.
"It won't prevent me from buying," Beulah Brown said yesterday as she pushed her cart, with two gallons of milk, down the aisles at the Pathmark at 125th Street and Lexington Avenue. At 89, she takes care of three grandchildren, including Isa, 8, who politely reminded her that she had forgotten to get ice cream.
In another aisle, Gwen Taylor was shopping for herself and her son, Lawrence, 7. In her cart were two half-gallons, one headed for the freezer at home to keep it from spoiling. 
"This is an hour's worth of work," said Ms. Taylor, a telemarketer who earns $7.50 an hour and works part time. "You got to work an hour for this milk." She shook her head. "We can't drink it all at once."

HEADLINE: Scientist Files Suit Over Anthrax Inquiry 

BYLINE:  By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
Dr. Steven J. Hatfill, whom senior government officials have identified as a "person of interest" in their investigation into the 2001 anthrax mailings, filed a lawsuit yesterday accusing Attorney General John Ashcroft and other Justice Department officials of having violated his constitutional rights and the agency's own rules by making him a "fall guy" in their inquiry.
 In the 40-page civil suit filed in Federal District Court in Washington, Dr. Hatfill asserted that Mr. Ashcroft and other Justice Department employees had ruined his life and violated his rights to free speech and privacy by making public information about him to cover their failure to make progress in the investigation of the anthrax attacks in the fall of 2001. The letters containing minute quantities of the deadly germ killed 5 people, infected 17 others and put thousands on antibiotics. 
 By publicly identifying Dr. Hatfill as a "person of interest" in the case and through other information given to the press and innuendos, the lawsuit says, Mr. Ashcroft and the other officials destroyed Dr. Hatfill's professional reputation, making him "not only unemployed, but as a practical matter unemployable."
The complaint said Justice Department officials had never previously used the term "person of interest."
Dr. Hatfill is seeking unspecified monetary damages from Mr. Ashcroft, the Justice Department, the F.B.I. and other current and former officials at those agencies.
A spokesman for the Justice Department said the agency would not comment on the suit or its charges. But he noted that H. Marshall Jarrett, the Justice Department counsel, found in January that Mr. Ashcroft had not engaged in professional misconduct or violated Justice Department rules by publicly describing Dr. Hatfill as a "person of interest."
Dr. Hatfill's suit won praise from L. Lin Wood, a lawyer for Richard Jewell, whom federal authorities and the news media identified, falsely it turned out, as the suspect in the 1996 Olympics bombing in Atlanta.
"I applaud the effort because I think we have to make sure there are checks and balances against the government," Mr. Wood said.
Dr. Hatfill is not the first scientist to file such a suit. In a lawsuit filed in late 1999, Dr. Wen Ho Lee accused the F.B.I. and the Justice and Energy Departments of engaging in a campaign of news leaks that violated his privacy and wrongfully portrayed him as a spy. The case is pending.
Dr. Hatfill's lawsuit details the alleged surveillance and harassment that he has endured and the substantial financial price he has paid since the government's inquiry began focusing on him last summer. It says that Dr. Hatfill, a medical doctor and an expert on biological weapons defense, cooperated with the government's inquiry for months.
The suit says he was dismissed from a teaching job at Louisiana State University after a campaign by officials "without producing any evidence against him, without officially naming him as a suspect," his lawyer, Thomas G. Connolly, said.
The suit says the F.B.I.'s constant physical and electronic surveillance of Dr. Hatfill and his home constitute undue harassment that "continue to prevent Dr. Hatfill from finding gainful employment, or enjoying any semblance of a normal life." It states that last May an F.B.I. agent tailing him struck Dr. Hatfill near his apartment in Georgetown. He was not seriously injured.
Government officials have said that Dr. Hatfill has come under suspicion partly because he worked for a time at the United States Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases at Fort Detrick in Frederick, Md. The lab is one of several government facilities that has stored the strain of anthrax that was found in the deadly anthrax letters.
But the complaint says that while the government has devoted "tens of thousands of man hours and tens of millions of dollars trying to pin the anthrax attacks" on Dr. Hatfill, it has found "no evidence" linking him to the crime.

HEADLINE: U.S. Corn Subsidies Said to Damage Mexico 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 

 BODY:
The more than $10 billion that American taxpayers give corn farmers every year in agricultural subsidies has helped destroy the livelihoods of millions of small Mexican farmers, according to a report to be released on Wednesday.
 Prepared in advance of critical trade talks next month, the report by Oxfam International argues that the subsidies given American corn farmers allow them to sell their grain at prices far below what it costs to produce. That has led to cheap American corn flooding the Mexican market and pushing the poorest Mexican farmers out of business, the report said. 
 "There is a direct link between government agricultural policies in the U.S. and rural misery in Mexico," according to the report entitled, "Dumping Without Borders: How U.S. agricultural policies are destroying the livelihoods of Mexican corn farmers." 
Like many other nongovernmental groups, Oxfam is working to promote changes in international rules at the meeting of the World Trade Organization in Cancun, Mexico, next month.
Mary Kay Thatcher of the American Farm Bureau Federation said that while it was obvious that American corn farmers received subsidies unavailable to Mexican farmers, that did not mean Americans had an unfair advantage. "In Mexico versus the U.S. it's a no-brainer," she said. "The Mexicans have far lower labor costs, lower land costs, input costs. To say that our subsidies are hurting Mexican farmers is ridiculous. It's not true."
Administration officials also rejected the idea that American exports to Mexico undermined farmers there. Julie Quick, a spokeswoman at the Agriculture Department, said that since most of the American corn exported to Mexico was used as animal feed for Mexico's rapidly expanding chicken and pork industries, it could not be undercutting small Mexican farmers who grow corn for human consumption.
"If we were dumping corn, then Mexico could file a complaint under the World Trade Organization, and Mexico has not," Ms. Quick said.
Trade and development experts atthe World Bank say that reducing or eliminating the agricultural subsidies and tariffs of wealthy nations would help developing nations more than any other single action.
The World Trade Organization has put changes in farm practices and trading rules at the top of its agenda during the current round of talks, which are dedicated to the developing world.
Mexico, the birthplace of corn, opened its borders to American corn exports after signing the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994. Within a year, corn imports from the United States doubled and today nearly one-third of the corn used in Mexico is imported from the United States. The United States is the biggest exporter of corn in the world and the biggest exporter of corn to Mexico.
The report said the price of Mexican corn has fallen more than 70 percent since Nafta took effect, severely reducing the incomes of the 15 million Mexicans who depend on corn for their livelihood.
But Bush administration officials said the Mexican government gave some price support to its corn farmers. The support is minimal, however, since the entire Mexican agricultural budget is only one-tenth the size of the subsidies given to American corn farmers alone, according to the Oxfam report.
Trade officials said today that agricultural trade had increased in both directions under Nafta, noting that Mexico's total agricultural exports to the United States had doubled under the agreement.
"The U.S. has been at the forefront working for ambitious and substantive global agricultural reform; we look forward to Mexicans joining us," said Richard Mills, the spokesman for the office of the United States trade representative.
A new statistical analysis of global subsidies released today argues otherwise, and says the wealthier nations have been undermining agriculture in the poor and developing world.
According to a study by the International Food Policy Research Institute, a nonprofit research organization, the agricultural policies of wealthy nations -- including tariffs, export subsidies and direct farm subsidies of over $300 billion every year -- cost developing nations about $24 billion every year in lost income.
Latin America and the Caribbean lose $8.3 billion each year, the largest sum of any region, according to the institute's report.
While both reports acknowledge that Mexico and other developing nations fail to provide enough support to their rural communities, their focus was to encourage wealthy nations to cut their subsidies. The institute's report concluded, "The fates of hundreds of millions of small-scale farmers and poor consumers in developing countries struggling to survive on a dollar or two of income a day hang in the balance."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A new report says Mexican farmers, like this one in Manzanillos, cannot compete against subsidized corn imported from the United States. (Photo by Lynsey Addario/Corbis)

HEADLINE: Study Finds Rise in Benefits For the Unemployed of 9/11 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
In one way at least, the thousands of New York City workers left jobless after 9/11 were luckier than those unemployed earlier or later -- because they were far more likely to collect benefits from New York State's unemployment insurance program. 
 That is the unexpected finding of a report to be released this week by the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University. It is based on questionnaires filled out by more than 2,500 New Yorkers in the five boroughs who were unemployed in 2001 or 2002. 
 Only 52 percent of those who became unemployed before 9/11 collected unemployment insurance benefits, the study found, but that percentage jumped to almost 65 percent in the months after the disaster. In 2002, however, the percentage fell to 56.5. 
The increases after 9/11 were particularly striking among those workers who are normally least likely to collect unemployment insurance: immigrants, low-wage workers and members of minority groups, according to the study.
The temporary increase came as something of a surprise to researchers, said Annette Bernhardt, senior policy analyst for the Brennan Center and an author of the report. It attributes the rise in benefits to the outpouring of assistance by government, charity, union and community groups, which informed jobless workers about their eligibility for benefits and helped them with the automated telephone application process.
"The lesson is that workers need help in accessing the unemployment insurance system," Dr. Bernhardt said. "They need a center that they can go to for information, staff that can help them figure out their eligibility, and translators to help them navigate what really is a complex application system." 
A spokesman for the New York State Department of Labor, Robert M. Lillpopp, said he had not seen the Brennan Center study and so could not comment on it. The department did not relax its rules on unemployment insurance eligibility after 9/11, he said.
But, he added, the department itself did extensive advertising to inform unemployed workers about benefits and other help. "We printed hundreds of thousands of palm cards in multiple languages -- English, Spanish, Chinese and Korean," he said, which were distributed at aid centers and job fairs.
And the state has since created a "language line" that connects people applying for benefits to someone who speaks their native tongue, Mr. Lillpopp said. The department now also allows people to apply over the Internet.
Critics of the state program frequently complain that workers who do not speak English or Spanish have difficulty navigating the system for getting and keeping benefits, a problem in a city where people speak everything from Albanian to Urdu. And a federal judge recently ruled that the state continues to reject applications improperly, despite some improvements.
Mark Humowiecki, a staff attorney at MFY Legal Services, said he was representing a worker whose native language is Bengali and whose English is limited. His client applied, ultimately successfully, for benefits, but then failed to navigate the automated system that those who receive benefits must use to check in every week. 
"I'm amazed at the number of hoops he has to go through just to get less than $200 a week in benefits," Mr. Humowiecki said, adding that his client has filed an appeal with the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Albany. 
New York State's unemployment insurance program provides up to six months of benefits for jobless people who qualify; the maximum payment is $405 a week, though the statewide average is less than $275, according to the federal Department of Labor. 
And even though most workers pay unemployment insurance taxes, only 44 percent of those statewide who lost their jobs collected benefits last year, according to federal data. 
The Brennan Center percentages were higher in part because of the way the questionnaires were distributed, Dr. Bernhardt said. Some participants filled them out with the assistance of community groups that had helped them to apply for benefits.

HEADLINE: Car Sales Slow Despite Spending on Incentives 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 26 

 BODY:
In another sign of how competitive the car market has become, auto companies spent a record amount on incentives in July, yet their vehicles sat unsold on dealers' lots for a record length of time.
 Moreover, Ford Motor and the Chrysler Corporation lost market share in July, though the average incentives for Detroit's auto companies grew to the highest level ever, according to Edmunds.com, a company in Santa Monica, Calif., that offers consumers buying advice and tracks industry trends. 
 In figures scheduled to be released on Wednesday, Edmunds estimates that car companies spent an average $2,668 on rebates, interest-free loans, lease deals and other discounts last month, up $519 or nearly 25 percent from July a year ago. Edmunds bases its calculations on industry sales data and transactions at dealerships. 
At the same time, Edmunds said the average time a vehicle spent in the showroom before being sold rose to 78 days in July. Put another way, that meant a vehicle that arrived on a dealer's lot on July 1 would not be sold until mid-September.
That compared with 54 days at the beginning of 2003, and 60 days in July 2002.
Normally, vehicles leave dealerships faster in the summer, when buyer traffic is strongest and auto companies are eager to clear their lots of leftover vehicles before the start of the new model year on Oct. 1. 
Increased incentives have generally translated to higher sales for the auto companies. But Jesse Toprak, a senior analyst at Edmunds, said the sluggish economy was upsetting longstanding industry patterns. Sales fell 4.5 percent in July, despite the historic incentives.
"The market doesn't act the way it's supposed to," Mr. Toprak said in an interview today.
According to Edmunds, the Big Three auto companies spent a record $3,631 a vehicle on incentives in July, compared with $1,873 for European auto companies, $1,447 for Korean automakers and $1,075 for Japanese auto companies.
Among individual companies, General Motors, which has been in the spotlight for its relentless approach to incentives in the last two years, spent a record $3,969 a vehicle in July, up 7 percent from June. But, G.M.'s efforts paid off, as it picked up 1.2 percentage points of market share, to 29.1 percent. A strong point for G.M. has been Cadillac, which has sold luxury cars like its CTS sedan with minimal incentives.
By contrast, Ford's spending on incentives rose 3.8 percent from June to $3,377 in July. But its market share last month dropped to 18.1 percent, "one of its lowest levels in the last several years," according to Edmunds.
Chrysler, whose chief executive, Dieter Zetsche, has likened rebates to heroin, was the only Detroit auto company to spend less on incentives in July. Its average was $3,192, down 9.2 percent from June. Chrysler's market share also fell, by 1.7 percentage points from June, to 11.8 percent, its lowest level since August 2001, Edmunds said.
Chrysler's decline put it perilously close to Toyota Motor, the fourth-best selling company in the United States. It gained seven-tenths of a point of market share in July, despite spending less on incentives, to reach 11.2 percent of the market, Edmunds said. Toyota's incentives were $962 per vehicle versus $1,008 in June, down 4.5 percent. Some Toyotas, like the new Sienna minivan, are commanding sticker price and above.
Honda Motor also gained one percentage point of market share in July, rising to 8.5 percent, while its average incentive rose 11 percent, to $467, from $420 in June, Edmunds said. Two models, the Pilot sport utility vehicle and the Element, a boxy crossover vehicle aimed at young customers, accounted for much of Honda's increase.
Mr. Toprak noted that the gains at Toyota and Honda came despite erosion in one of their traditional market strengths: midsize cars. Last month, sales of midsize cars like the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord accounted for only 15.7 percent of the market, down from nearly 20 percent as recently as January 2001. By contrast, large pickup trucks took 14.5 percent of the car market in July, up from 12.5 percent at the beginning of last year.

HEADLINE: High School Seniors Get Highest SAT Math Scores in 35 Years 

BYLINE:  By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 

 BODY:
The scores of high school seniors on the SAT math exam have climbed to their highest level in 35 years. Experts tied the gain to the growing number of students learning algebra in the eighth grade and taking more advanced courses in math after reaching high school.
 The average math score was 519, out of a possible 800. 
 Educators around the country hailed the results of the 2003 SAT tests, released here today, as good news, with some reservations: the scores of students from rural areas and large cities continued to lag, and women continued to lag behind men, particularly in math. 
The results appeared to overturn the traditional equation that shows test scores falling as more and more students take the exams. This year, a record number of students, 1.4 million, took the SAT, but scores rose three points each in both the math and verbal sections of the exam.
"A lot of work has been done to improve math, and it's beginning to pay off," said Gaston Caperton, president of the College Board, which sponsors the test.
But Mr. Caperton, a former governor of West Virginia, said that after looking at the results, he worried that "not enough money" was going to impoverished schools under the new federal education act, No Child Left Behind.
"A democracy really depends on equal opportunity for an education, and these figures show that we're not providing that equal opportunity," Mr. Caperton said. "In large cities and rural areas, you see they're really still behind. They're really not catching up, and that's what concerns us. That's what No Child Left Behind was really focused toward."
Today's results appeared to contrast sharply with the results of the ACT, another college entrance exam, released last week. Those results showed student scores holding steady, but at a level indicating that a majority of students were unprepared for college-level work in math or science.
Three years ago, however, the ACT organization signed contracts to administer its exam to all high school students in Illinois and Colorado, expanding the pool of test-takers to include many students who had no intention of attending college, said Jon Erickson, vice president for educational services at ACT.
An increase of a few points on the SAT "or a stable score on the ACT are in some ways representing the same news," Mr. Erickson said. Students who took their high school's college preparation curriculum, which typically includes a foreign language and higher levels of math and science, also increased their scores on the ACT, he said.
In addition, said Cyndie Schmeiser, the vice president for development at ACT, the two exams measure different kinds of learning. The ACT tests knowledge of the curriculum for a given subject, while the SAT more generally measures aptitude and the ability to reason. Unlike the SAT, the ACT results showed no gap between the performance of men and women.
The average math SAT score of 519 represented a 16-point gain over the last decade, while the average verbal score of 507 represented a 7-point gain.
Henry Levin, a professor of economics and education at Teachers College, Columbia University, attributed the "reasonably good improvement" to the increased competition among high school students for admission to selective colleges and universities. That has led more students to tackle hard courses, including Advanced Placement courses, he said.
"School districts have vastly increased the numbers of students in these courses and the numbers of courses available," Professor Levin said. "Kids who in the past would not have taken A.P. courses are now being encouraged to take them."
Educators were also watching today's results for the performance of states like North Carolina and Texas, which have been in the forefront of the standardized testing movement. Texas, in particular, has served as a model for No Child Left Behind, which requires annual testing of students in math and reading from third through eighth grade. Until last year, its state exam, the Texas Assessment of Academic Skills, showed steady gains in performance among high school students.
But the SAT scores of Texas seniors improved only slightly over the last decade, by two points in math and three points in verbal skills. At 500 in math and 493 in verbal skills, the Texas scores fell below national averages. In the same period, the numbers of students taking the SAT in Texas grew only slightly faster than the national average.
But the number of black and Latino students taking the SAT grew by about 50 percent in the past decade, said Debbie Graves Ratcliffe, a spokeswoman for the Texas Education Agency. "We think it's a good sign because we're really encouraging more kids to think about college as an option."
But with scores in Texas seemingly stagnating on both the SAT this week and on the ACT last week, state officials were concerned. "I think it's a sign that we need to look at the math curriculum and how students are doing in their courses," Ms. Ratcliffe said.
"A lot of our reforms have been aimed at the elementary level," she added. "We've yet to see that translated into big performance gains at the high school level." She added that the State Legislature recently appropriated $100 million to improve high school instruction. "Hopefully, that will pay off."

HEADLINE: Critics Say Housing Proposal Would Worsen a Shortage 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

DATELINE: TRENTON, Aug. 26 

 BODY:
Advocates for moderately priced housing are reacting angrily to a state proposal that would substantially ease requirements for such housing in the suburbs. 
 The proposal, unveiled Monday by the Council on Affordable Housing, the state board that sets housing policy, was praised by municipal leaders, who have long complained that the state's housing regulations encourage suburban sprawl. But critics say the plan would increase racial and economic segregation and worsen New Jersey's severe shortage of modestly priced homes. 
 "Today is a sad day," said Kevin D. Walsh, a staff lawyer with the Fair Share Housing Center, a nonprofit agency in Cherry Hill. "This proposal will result in the continued ghettoization of Camden, Trenton and Newark," three cities that have significant proportions of low-income minority residents. 
Since 1975, when the State Supreme Court handed down a ruling that came to be known as the Mount Laurel decision for the township whose zoning had been challenged, New Jersey municipalities have been legally bound to provide a "fair share" of low- and moderately priced homes, a quota based on factors including projected population growth and the amount of undeveloped land. Regulations based on the ruling were intended to circumvent exclusionary zoning laws and encourage integration in the suburbs, but they were so complicated that builders began using them to force communities to accept unwanted development.
Under the plan unveiled Monday, the number of new low-income housing units required would be tied to growth: communities would be required to provide one low-income home for every 10 market-priced homes they approve and every 30 jobs that are created. Communities that do not want any new development would no longer be forced to add low-income housing.
Susan Bass Levin, the state community affairs commissioner, whose department oversees housing policy, said the new proposal would give municipal officials more power to regulate growth and make it harder for builders to use the Mount Laurel ruling to develop land set aside for preservation as open space.
"The current system didn't work," said Ms. Levin, who is also the chairwoman of the Council on Affordable Housing. "It is overcomplicated, overly bureaucratic, and didn't produce the results it should have. The new approach balances the need for affordable housing with the need for towns and communities to plan their growth sensibly." 
Diane Sterner, executive director of the Housing and Community Development Network of New Jersey, a nonprofit group, said she supported an overhaul of the state's housing laws because only 37,000 moderately priced units had been built in 17 years -- more per capita than most other states, but far too few to ease the state's housing shortage. But she said the new proposal offered townships so many loopholes thatthey could completely avoid building low-income housing.
"They've diluted the Mount Laurel mandates to a point where nothing is going to happen," she said. "The methodology and the numbers are horrendous." 
After a public comment period, the 11-member board of the Council on Affordable Housing will vote on whether to adopt the new proposal. 
William G. Dressel Jr., executive director of the New Jersey League of Municipalities, said the new rules were far simpler and would allow township and borough leaders to avoid the lawsuits that have allowed developers to pave over open space. 
"I have faith that when people adjust to these new regulations, it will work out better for everyone," he said.
But Mr. Walsh, the lawyer for Fair Share Housing, said he and other advocates were prepared to challenge the new rules in court unless they were substantially modified. "We aren't going to sit down while Mount Laurel is trampled on," he said.

 BODY:
U.S. Crop Policy Is Said To Hurt Mexican Farmers
The more than $10 billion that American taxpayers give corn farmers every year in agricultural subsidies has helped destroy the livelihoods of millions of small Mexican farmers, according to a report by Oxfam International.
 The report says that the subsidies given to American corn farmers allow them to sell their grain at prices far below what it costs to produce. That has led to cheap American corn flooding the Mexican market and pushing the poorest Mexican farmers out of business, according to the report. Page C4. 

Economic Data Point to Recovery
Americans bought newly built homes and expensive manufactured goods at a brisk pace in July and a report on August consumer confidence was surprisingly strong. The Commerce Department said that orders for durable goods rose 1 percent in July, and the Conference Board said that its index of consumer confidence rose to 81.3 in August from an upwardly revised 77 in July. HEADLINE: Home Sales Remain Strong; Confidence Index Climbs 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 

 BODY:
Americans bought newly built homes and expensive manufactured goods at a brisk pace in July, and a report on consumer confidence this month was surprisingly strong, indicating that an economic recovery is on course.
 The government said today that sales of new homes fell slightly in July. But the total was still ahead of expectations because the record high sales pace of June was revised upward. 
 While down 2.9 percent from June, sales of new homes in July were still at the second-highest level on record.
The Commerce Department said that orders for durable goods rose 1 percent in July, and the Conference Board said that its index of consumer confidence rose to 81.3 in August from an upwardly revised 77 in July. But the confidence survey also suggested that job seekers were still having a hard time finding work.
"The general conclusion that I would draw is that the recovery is gaining momentum but a large proportion of the population are still waiting for some more proof," said Mark Vitner, an economist at Wachovia Securities.
Stocks sagged, with analysts saying that the good news had already been priced into the market. Treasury securities initially fell in price after the data but then rallied as equities sank. 
Demand for cars led the increases in durable goods orders, but there were increases across the board. Orders of motor vehicles and parts surged 5.5 percent and machinery orders climbed 1.8 percent, while demand for computers and electronics rose 1.9 percent.
Excluding transportation, orders rose 1.7 percent, and without spending on the military, orders were up 1.4 percent.
"Over all, it's a healthy report," said Mike Niemira, senior economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi. "I think it continues the very upbeat picture that has been painted now for a couple of months, that manufacturing is finally coming out of its slump."
The home-sales report showed that even as the housing boom began to slow as mortgage interest rates rose from 40-year lows, home buying remained attractive.
Sales of new single-family homes slipped to a seasonally adjusted 1.165 million annual rate -- the second-highest pace on record.
"The housing market remains strong," said Mickey Levy, chief economist at Banc of America Securities. "One piece of data that jumps out is that inventories of unsold homes are very, very low, suggesting that even through the end of the year, you're going to see continued construction strength."
Inventories equaled June's record low of a 3.5-month supply of homes available at the current sales pace.
In another good sign for the economy, consumers said they felt more optimistic in August about the future. The Conference Board's confidence index showed that the expectations component climbed to 94.4 from 86.3 over the last month.
But pointing to the current conditions index, which declined to 61.6 from 63.0, analysts offered a word of caution about the report.
"The consumer number isn't really as good as it looks," said Drew Matus, economist at Lehman Brothers. "The labor market is still holding back people's confidence, and in the long run will probably hold back people's willingness to spend additional money."

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
Giant Mallof America Plans to Be Even Bigger

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: BLOOMINGTON, Minn. 

 BODY:
The decor is a little dated, but 11 years after its opening, the Mall of America is still the nation's biggest shopping and entertainment center, with 2.5 million square feet of retail space surrounding a bustling amusement park and at least 40 million visitors a year.
 But to the developers of the mall, it is not big enough. In June, Ikea began building a 330,000-square-foot store on 15 acres that it bought from the Simon Property Group, the mall's managing partner. Expected to open June, the new Ikea store will be across the street from Nordstrom, one of the shopping center's four anchors. 
 Simon and the other investors in the mall hope that the arrival of the popular home-furnishings giant -- whose closest store at present is in the Chicago suburb of Schaumburg, Ill., about 400 miles away from this Minneapolis-St. Paul suburb -- will jump-start a second phase of construction that will expand the Mall of America, which is already home to more than 500 stores and theme restaurants. 
The development of the 43-acre site, just north of the mall, has been stalled by the faltering economy and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, which raised fears that the shopping center might be a likely target. 
The mall has also been at the center of a federal lawsuit in which the Triple Five Group, one of the developers, has accused Simon, the world's largest retail real estate investment trust, of secretly negotiating in 1998 with a third partner, TIAA-CREF, the financial services company, to gain control of the shopping center.
Triple Five, a company with headquarters in Las Vegas and Edmonton, Alberta, that is run by the Ghermezian family, the developers of the even larger 5.3-million-square-foot West Edmonton Mall, is seeking to replace Simon as managing partner of the mall. Testimony in the nonjury trial ended on Aug. 11, and a ruling is expected within a few weeks.
Despite these distractions, Maureen Bausch, the vice president for business development, said the mall was actively seeking tenants for the vacant expansion site. Tentative plans call for the addition of three hotels, a spa and an office building, as well as entertainment attractions, perhaps including a performing arts center. Additional retail space might be devoted to categories that are not widely available at the mall like electronics and home furnishings, Ms. Bausch said. The size of the project has not been determined, a Simon spokesman, Les Morris, said. 
Ikea characterizes its project as a free-standing store rather than an anchor for the mall's second phase. "We are using the term 'neighbor,' " an Ikea spokesman, Joseph E. Roth, said. "But that said, we will be a major catalyst for further enhancing the retail destination that is the Mall of America." Ikea, which has 18 stores in this country, announced plans in January to add 50 stores in North America in 10 years. The store here will not be connected to the original Mall of America, but a skywalk will link it to the hub of the new shopping area, Mr. Roth said.
Now that more than a decade has passed, the mall is undergoing some modifications, with about 65 tenants either moving to new locations or modernizing their stores, Ms. Bausch said. The common areas are also being spruced up, and the bathrooms are being updated, a mall spokeswoman, Monica Davis, said.
Stores that appeal to certain types of customers are being grouped together. Therese Byrne, a New York retail real estate consultant who has advised the mall, said it needed to appeal to a broader range of shoppers. "They need to appeal to the sophisticated customer," she said.
Just how successful is the Mall of America? Traffic at the mall has returned to pre-Sept. 11 levels, with visitors from outside a 150-mile radius of the mall holding steady at about 35 percent, Ms. Bausch said. But while about 25 percent of the tourists used to come by air, these days as few as 18 percent do, according to a survey conducted by the mall last summer.
In documents filed earlier this year with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Simon reported that the mall was 97 percent occupied. Ms. Bausch estimated that about 20 of the tenants (apart from the 70 kiosks) are temporary, many of them fledgling concepts brought in under the mall's retail incubator program.
In testimony at the trial, the two sides offered wildly different assessments of the mall, which was built on the site of the Minnesota Vikings' former stadium. It was the Ghermezians who came up with the idea of building a lavishly scaled mall combining entertainment and shopping, and who landed the right to develop the project in 1985. They later brought in Simon (then known as Melvin Simon & Associates) as a development partner and manager. 
TIAA-CREF provided the entire $650 million in equity financing and acquired a 55 percent stake in the shopping center, with the other partners getting 22.5 percent each. In 1999, TIAA-CREF sold half its stake to Simon for $318 million, including $160 million in cash and the assumption of $134 million in debt. TIAA-CREF also received $24 million in preferred stock.
In the suit, a lawyer for the Ghermezians, Roger J. Magnuson, has argued that Simon, which also has other ventures with TIAA-CREF, made the deal behind his clients' back and stands to gain hundreds of millions of dollars in profits. 
But Simon maintains that the Ghermezians were fully aware of the deal, had no money to invest in the project and simply wanted to get Simon to pay heavy damages. "This lawsuit," a Simon lawyer, Lawrence J. Field, said in his closing argument, "was an attempt to squeeze the Simons, to force the defendants to make Triple Five happy by giving them something for nothing."
During the trial, Simon has sought to minimize the value of the mall, saying it brings in about $40 million a year in earnings and estimating its worth at $540 million.
By contrast, an appraiser hired by the Ghermezians testified that the mall, together with the amusement park, is worth about $745 million, a figure that would climb to about $984 million once the second phase is completed.
Simon does not report sales figures for individual malls, but its chief executive, David Simon, testified that the Mall of America does less well than some other Simon properties, like the Forum Shops at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, because it does not draw luxury retailers and has lost out to other malls when competing for tenants like the Cheesecake Factory and Crate and Barrel. Mr. Simon told the court that the mall management recovers 70 percent of its costs for taxes, insurance, common area maintenance and marketing, less than at other malls.
By contrast, an expert witness for the Ghermezians testified that sales for stores of 10,000 square feet or less run about $530 a square foot, much more than the $330 average.
Retail real estate specialists say the Mall of America poses a challenge to store owners, who pay heavy additional charges for common areas, insurance, security and property taxes.
"Getting your share of the market is difficult," said Steven B. Greenberg, the president of the Greenberg Group, which advises specialty retailers. "You have to consummate a sale early. There tends to be sense of, 'I've got so much to see, I've got to move on.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn. An expansion is planned for the mall, which is already home to more than 500 stores and restaurants. (Photo by Craig Lassig for The New York Times) Map of Bloomington, Minnesota, highlighting the location of the Mall of America.

HEADLINE: When Airlines Share, Consumers Win 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 If government approval of alliances between airlines will aid the balance sheets of some American air carriers and keep thousands of airline workers employed, maybe that is a good thing. 
 Robert Crandall ("Thank You for Flying Whatever Airline This Is," Op-Ed, Aug. 23) expresses concern about the decreasing presence of United States carriers on transAtlantic flights and the loss of thousands of American jobs. 
The United States' presence over the Atlantic could have increased dramatically if American Airlines had taken advantage of all the international routes it acquired from the purchase of T.W.A.

HEADLINE: Japan's Bulls Chilled by Cool Snap 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 26 

 BODY:
Just as the bulls were starting to return to Tokyo, Japan's economy appears to have hit a bump on the road to recovery. The culprit this time is not the banks or a major corporate collapse, but the coldest summer in a decade.
 In theory, a few extra weeks of rain and chill should not derail a $4.4 trillion economy. But in Japan, where most full-time workers receive their bonuses in June and July and take vacations in August, the summer months are akin to the Christmas shopping season in the United States. 
 For companies in a range of industries, from beverages to electronics to travel, the months from June to August are crucial. Yet temperatures in Tokyo have been almost three degrees Celsius below average and the capital has received just two-thirds as much sunshine this summer, hurting sales of everything from bathing suits to beer.
 The cold snap and longer-than-usual rainy season, which typically ends in early July in Tokyo, could shave as much as half a percentage point off Japan's growth rate in the July-September quarter, according to some estimates, a significant amount considering that the economy grew at an annual rate of 2.3 percent from April to June.
 "We're already seeing an impact from the summer blues on retail spending, and the dreary holidays in August may have killed leisure spending as well," said Ryo Hino, an economist at J.P. Morgan Securities in Tokyo.
 While not enough to bring on a recession, the slower sales could dent the largest and most vulnerable part of the economy -- consumer spending. They may also force Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi to consider more pump-priming measures. This could strain the budget and force Mr. Koizumi to reverse his pledge to restrain the budget deficit just ahead of general elections expected this autumn. One of Mr. Koizumi's leading critics, Shizuka Kamei, a senior member of Mr. Koizumi's party, said today that he wanted the government to spend an additional 10 trillion yen ($83 billion) this year.
 Companies, however, are not waiting for government handouts; they are cutting sales and profit targets. Supermarket chains, like Ito-Yokado, Seiyu and Aeon, and Japan's two largest beer brewers, Asahi and Kirin, recently cut their earnings forecasts sharply.
 Over all, supermarket sales declined 5 percent in July compared with a year earlier, while spending at convenience stores fell a record 7.3 percent. Sales at 7-Eleven Japan, the country's largest chain of convenience shops, tumbled 4.9 percent even though managers reintroduced oden and nikuman, two foods suited to colder weather, according to a company spokesman, Tetsuhiro Kaneko. (Oden are various foods simmered in a fish broth, and nikuman is a meat-filled dumpling.)
 Prices for fresh vegetables and fruit have also risen, and this year's rice crop is expected to be worse than usual, which could force the government to release some of its emergency stockpiles. Ito-Yokado said sales of peaches, watermelons and other high-price summer fruit had plunged as prices spiked.
 And economists expect consumer price figures, to be released Friday, to confirm this trend.
 Electronics companies like Matsushita Electric Industrial and Toshiba say sales of air-conditioners fell almost 30 percent in July, in line with the industry as a whole.
 The colder, wetter weather has also put a damper on Japan's 10.8 trillion yen ($90 billion) travel industry. Most major railways have had fewer travelers this summer. The airlines likewise had fewer passengers on international routes -- partly because of the lingering effects of SARS -- though the airlines reported small gains in domestic traffic.
 Casualty insurers have also suffered, with a surge in claims from victims of water damage.
 Taken together, the decline in sales and the resulting effect on corporate profits could reduce the gross domestic product by about 1 trillion yen ($8.3 billion) in the second half of this year, according to the Dai-ichi Life Research Institute.
 Every cloud, though, has a silver lining. Earlier this year, the Tokyo Electric Power Company was forced to shut its nuclear power plants for safety inspections, leading analysts to predict that Tokyo would face brownouts if the summer was hotter than usual. The unseasonably cool weather, though, led to a record decline in power consumption in July, giving the utility some breathing room to restart its power plants.
 Summer bonuses also rose a healthy 3.14 percent this year, with payments to workers at manufacturers growing at their fastest rate since 1990.
 What workers do with that money is crucial. If they put it into savings accounts, it may be spent later. But apart from the weather, economists say other factors are eroding spending. An increase in social security insurance premiums in April is taking a bigger bite out of bonuses this year, they said, while higher food prices and recent increases in tobacco and liquor taxes have also undermined purchasing power.
