HEADLINE: Hospitals Pressured By Soaring Demand For Obesity Surgery 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Doctors and hospitals across the country are scrambling to satisfy the booming demand for surgery that shrinks the stomachs of severely obese people.
 Dozens of hospitals are adding special operating suites for the procedure, called bariatric surgery, which attracted wide notice after public figures like Al Roker of "Today" on NBC, Sharon Osbourne of "The Osbournes" on MTV and Representative Jerrold Nadler, a Manhattan Democrat, had it done. Some bariatric surgeons are fully scheduled 12 months in advance, and hundreds of doctors have jumped into the field recently and started to advertise their availability. 
 Bariatric procedures -- meant for obese people who are at extremely high risk of severe health problems, as defined by a National Institutes of Health consensus -- surged more than 40 percent last year, to 80,000. This year, the number is expected to climb to 120,000, according to Frost & Sullivan, a consulting firm. Spending on bariatrics is approaching $3 billion a year, at an average cost of $25,000 for each procedure. 
With the number of people eligible for the procedures growing by an estimated 10 to 12 percent a year, bariatric surgery can be profitable for hospitals -- and even more so for surgeons. But the costs are a major concern for insurance companies and employer health plans. Surgeons say that some insurers routinely delay approvals.
"The companies throw up roadblocks," said Dr. James Rosser, a surgeon at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. "They keep requesting more information. Patients are left to really hound the insurance companies to get the approvals."
Doctors and patients, meanwhile, are putting pressure on insurers to lower the body-size threshold for paying for the operation for people who have advanced problems with diabetes and other weight-related diseases. That could triple the number of people potentially eligible for the operation to more than 30 million, a panel of medical advisers to the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield association was told recently.
One group having trouble winning access to treatment is the poor, among whom obesity is an especially acute concern. Doctors say that Medicaid programs in many states have been reluctant to pay for the procedures. At the University of California at Davis, for example, Medi-Cal patients face a 12-year wait for bariatric surgery, said Dr. Bruce M. Wolfe, a bariatric surgeon and professor of surgery. Medi-Cal reimburses Davis for the procedure at less than a third of the hospital's cost.
"Basically they're not getting access to the care," he said. "They will suffer the consequences of untreated obesity." 
Most bariatric procedures produce weight loss by restricting the intake of food. Part of the stomach is partitioned off and the intestines are rerouted. Afterward, many patients lose their outsize appetites. 
"Patients can eat smaller amounts and feel satisfied," said Dr. Alan C. Wittgrove, a San Diego surgeon who is president of the American Society for Bariatric Surgery. But there can also be unpleasant consequences: if they eat too much, patients may vomit. 
The procedure is approved for patients at the upper end of the body mass index, a measure of weight in relation to height. Under National Institutes of Health guidelines, widely followed by health plans, candidates must first try diet and exercise regimens. 
More than 10 million Americans, 4.7 percent of the population, are eligible for the procedure, according to the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases of the National Institutes of Health.
In addition to the average cost of $25,000 for the surgery and associated services, lifelong follow-up is strongly recommended, adding to costs. "They need support groups, follow-up by nurses, exercise programs," Dr. Wittgrove said. Insurance companies often do not pay for these programs or for counseling, Dr. Rosser added.
For some patients, overall costs can be much more, up to $100,000, said Helen Darling, president of the Washington Business Group on Health. Her organization, which represents large employers, recently opened a campaign to encourage overweight workers to slim down. 
A spokesman for that campaign, Dr. Vincent Kerr, director of health care management at the Ford Motor Company, estimates that obese workers cost employers $12 billion annually in medical bills, reduced productivity, increased absenteeism and higher insurance premiums.
The National Institutes of Health, meanwhile, says that the annual costs of treating obesity-related conditions -- including diabetes, heart disease, osteoarthritis and breast and colon cancers -- are at least $120 billion.
Bariatric specialists say the surgery reduces those costs in the long run. Patients with Type 2 diabetes, which the N.I.H. said accounted for $98 billion of obesity-related costs, have normal sugar counts within a few days after the stomach bypass procedure, without medication, Dr. Wittgrove said. 
A recent study by the Blue Cross and Blue Shield association "confirmed that surgery is far more effective than diet and exercise in treating morbid obese patients," said Naomi Aronson, executive director of the association's technology evaluation center.
But the long-term payoff has yet to be proved, said Dr. Alan M. Garber, a health economist at Stanford University who is a member of the association's medical advisory panel. "Something of a leap of faith is involved," he said.
Health insurers will cover the cost only for patients who meet a long list of preconditions, partly based on N.I.H. criteria. Aetna, for example, requires that candidates for the procedure have spent six months in a diet and exercise program supervised by a physician.
"Insurance companies, unfortunately are somewhat schizophrenic about this procedure," Dr. Wittgrove said. "Some authorize it quite easily and are patient-friendly. They seem to get the fact that they are going to save money over all." But, he added, "other insurance companies want to put hurdles in front of patients rather than facilitate treatment." 
Some of the most active hospitals for bariatric procedures are in 
California, New York and Boston. But a number of hospitals in Indiana are adding bariatric facilities. And in Florida, "just in the last six months in my neighborhood in Coral Gables, six surgeons have begun to advertise bariatric surgery," said Dr. Eneida O. Roldan, a physician who is chairwoman of the American Board of Bariatric Medicine, an accrediting group.
Hospitals in New York State reported 4,670 procedures last year, up 50 percent from 2001 and more than double the 1,981 in 2000, said Karen Heller, a senior health care economist at the Greater New York Hospital Association. 
Dr. Rosser, the Manhattan surgeon, has personal knowledge of both obesity and bariatric care. A one-time high school football player, he later soared to 450 pounds on a 6-foot-4 frame. 
"I had sleep apnea, a very prevalent silent killer, and muscular-skeletal aches and pains," said Dr. Rosser, a specialist in laparoscopic surgery who does bariatric procedures with miniature instruments. "I could see the handwriting on the wall." 
He said he made "the maximum effort to lose weight for four years, but the weight came back." Two years ago, when he was 46, Dr. Rosser underwent the surgery. He has since lost 150 pounds -- and he shows his patients a video relating his story.
In California, Kaiser Permanente, the big health maintenance organization, is tripling its bariatric surgery capacity in the San Francisco area. "There has been a tremendous increase in demand in the last four years," said Dr. Michelle Caughey, physician in chief of Kaiser's South San Francisco Medical Center, which treats 420 bariatric cases a year. 
Kaiser recently added two centers nearby. Combined, they expect to handle more than 1,200 cases by the end of next year, she said. 
New centers like Kaiser's are big customers for special equipment. They buy beds four feet wide that can support "patients of size," who may weigh up to 1,000 pounds, said Lynne Sly, vice president at Kinetic Concepts, a bed manufacturer in San Antonio. With extras like built-in scales, the special beds can cost more than $20,000, or $170 a day to rent.
Sales of these beds and accessories have been growing 21 percent a year, another indicator of the trends in obesity surgery, said Dhiraj Ajmani, an analyst at Frost & Sullivan, the consultants.
Dr. Wolfe at U.C. Davis said that bariatric procedures were only "profitable by a small margin" for hospitals. Complications are frequent, and the procedures often require extra employees in the operating room, he said. 
But with demand so strong from patients, many bariatric surgeons are thriving, Dr. Wolfe added. 
"Morbid obesity is life-threatening, and surgery is the only treatment that works," he said. "The hospitals don't have much choice but to respond."

HEADLINE: COUNCIL CONTESTS: 18th District -- Bronx; 
Unions' Interest Ratchets Up the Intrigue in a Bronx Race

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Pedro Gautier Espada is 29 years old, and his current race for City Council in the Bronx represents the ninth time that he has campaigned for political or public office. And given a similar number of races undertaken by his father, City Councilman Pedro Espada Jr., the younger Mr. Espada has seen more than his share of Bronx politics.
 Indeed, there always seems to be an Espada running for some office in the Bronx. But never have voters had the experience of seeing one Espada substitute for another on the ballot. That is what occurred a few months ago in the 18th Council District, when the elder Mr. Espada, who is the incumbent, decided to pull out of his re-election race and have his son as the substitute on the ballot. 
 The younger Mr. Espada once served in the Assembly and represented an adjacent district in the Council until the end of 2001. But he has not faced a race like that waged by his opponent for the Democratic nomination, Annabel Palma.
Ms. Palma, 31, is a union organizer with 1199/S.E.I.U. whose first venture into elective politics has apparently touched a chord among labor groups. On any given afternoon, Ms. Palma's campaign headquarters is filled with many of the hundreds of campaign volunteers in what seems to be a crusade by labor groups to elect one of their own.
The Espada family is well known as a political powerhouse in the Bronx. The elder Mr. Espada operated a large health care clinic and employs hundreds of people, most of them voters in the district. The councilman and his son typically run against candidates whose major benefactor is the Bronx Democratic Party organization.
Indeed, over the years, the Espadas have become the archenemies of the Democratic Party, which took the unusual step of going to court to have the elder Mr. Espada expelled from the party after he announced -- when he was a state senator -- that he was planning to become a Republican and began sitting with Republicans in the Senate. (The elder Mr. Espada said he withdrew from the Council race because the party was resurrecting legal proceedings against him.)
But this race is different. Ms. Palma went to the Democratic Party for support after she had met with union leaders and neighbors. And she has the support of a wide range of Democratic figures, from Borough President Adolfo Carrion Jr. and former Mayor David N. Dinkins to the Rev. Al Sharpton. But what makes this race intriguing to many Bronx Democrats is that so many labor unions have become heavily involved.
And it is a district with a strong labor base in the electorate. Ms. Palma's union, 1199, which represents health care workers, has nearly 4,000 members who are registered Democrats in the district, and the Transport Workers Union and Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, two groups that strongly support her candidacy, have between them 2,400 registered voters.
Ms. Palma said that her appeal is largely due to the fact that she is not a professional politician and portrays herself as a working single mother. "I am just a regular member of this community," she said in an interview at her headquarters, whose walls are plastered with campaign data for volunteers.
"My focus in this race is on the fact that people here need jobs and that they want economic development and they want affordable housing," she said. "And those are the things I'm committed to."
She rarely if ever mentions Mr. Espada, saying that "the needs of the community are what's important."
Mr. Espada, however, describes his opponent as a "candidate who has been hired to take out another candidate," contending that Ms. Palma and the 1199 were retained by the Bronx Democratic Party to run against him.
He said he is eager to return to the City Council, where he served for four years before he was defeated in the 2001 primary, to focus specifically on education. "I particularly want to be involved in the reform of special education," he said. He said he also wants to ensure that affordable housing is available to the district, especially in areas like Parkchester, where development has pushed up housing prices and rents.
The race in this district, which includes Soundview and Castle Hill, is being eagerly watched. Mr. Espada, who is not participating in the city's campaign finance program, said his campaign has raised "somewhere between $30,000 and $40,000." He and his father have always waged well-financed campaigns with hundreds of volunteers.
Ms. Palma has raised $83,000 from 600 contributors (she has the third-highest number of donors of the more than 120 candidates in the program). And she has received an additional $77,500 in matching funds.

HEADLINE: Pact to Help Poor Nations Obtain Drugs Is Delayed 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 

 BODY:
The World Trade Organization came close tonight to approving an agreement to help poor nations buy lifesaving generic medicines through new exemptions from trade rules, only to postpone the final decision.
 Shortly before midnight at the organization's headquarters in Geneva, its top negotiating committee recommended that the full council accept the resolution, and the full council immediately convened to do so. 
 But several countries asked for further clarifications, and the meeting was adjourned to permit them more time, several diplomats said in telephone interviews from Geneva.
"I think it is going to be approved, but we never got to the stage of discussions," said Nelson Ndirangu of the Kenya delegation. 
Representatives of Argentina and the Philippines said earlier that they were worried about several interpretations of the proposal.
The speed of these deliberations reflects the importance of the measure for developing countries that cannot afford the high prices of patented medicines for treating millions of their citizens who suffer from AIDS and other diseases.
This week, the United States reversed its earlier opposition and agreed to support the measure, a move that offered some momentum for the global trade talks being held next month in Mexico.
The poorest countries have campaigned for years for the right to buy inexpensive generic equivalents of advanced medicines patented by some of the world's largest multinational corporations, saying that intellectual property rights should not override the needs of poor people threatened by disease.
The organization regulates trade-related intellectual property rights, including those covering patented medicines.
Under existing rules, poor countries have the right to manufacture copycat versions of brand-name medicines in the event of a health emergency, by issuing what is called a compulsory license to a local manufacturer without needing the patent holder's permission.
Most poor countries, however, lack the ability to make such drugs, and the existing rules forbid exports of generic drugs by the few countries that can make them. The pending trade agreement would ease that restriction and permit nations like Brazil and India to export compulsory-licensed generic drugs to other poor countries under certain conditions.
"It is very disappointing," said Keith Rockwell, the trade organization's spokesman, in a telephone interview from Geneva early on Friday morning. "There is no deal; more consultations are required." 
The organization was on the verge of approving a new agreement once before, in December, but the United States single-handedly blocked the deal then, citing concerns from the American pharmaceutical industry.
To show good faith, the Bush administration pledged that it would not pursue unfair-trade complaints against countries that broke the existing rules to export cut-rate medicines to poor countries until a new deal was brokered.
But the other countries of the trade organization, including some of the closest allies of the United States, strongly criticized the Bush administration for obstructing one of the few international trade agreements that could be said to address humanitarian and economic concerns.
After weeks of intensive negotiations this summer, the United States changed its mind. A group of nations -- including Brazil and India, both of them large producers of generic drugs, as well as South Africa and Kenya -- worked out the deal with the United States that was recommended tonight for approval.
It offers new assurances that countries that produce generic drugs will not exploit the arrangement to increase exports of generic drugs to nations that are not poor and do not have a medical emergency, diplomats involved in the discussions said. 
In return, the United States dropped its demands for a sharp narrowing of the agreement to cover drugs for only four diseases and shipments to only a limited number of countries.
"The U.S.A. had its bluff called by the developing countries, and pretty much caved in," said James Love of the Consumer Project on Technology, a nonprofit organization that lobbied heavily for an agreement.
Medical and development experts said that the new agreement, if adopted, would break down a big barrier to providing lifesaving medicines.
"This gives us a big advantage if we eventually want to reach the scale of treating millions of people," said Joep Lange, president of the International AIDS Society, in a telephone interview from the Netherlands.
Mr. Lange said it was important for the pharmaceutical companies to accept the new measure and continue financing research into new treatments for the diseases.
While advocacy groups for AIDS patients were among the loudest voices campaigning for freer trade in generic medicines for the developing world, experts say the need is also great for drugs to treat tuberculosis, malaria and other diseases.
Officials of the American pharmaceutical industry said tonight that they were pleased with the deal, but that they would have no more specific comment until the trade organization as a whole reaches a consensus on it.

HEADLINE: Sad to See Summer End? Travel Industry Is, Too 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

 BODY:
Long lines at airports, car-rental counters and hotel registration desks this Labor Day weekend are of little consolation to the weary travel industry, which is already looking past them to expectations of another difficult fall.
 Analysts and executives said they feared that the travel industry's woes would return, even before the last summer-vacation suitcase is unpacked. 
 The sluggish business climate is simply too much of a damper to provide any hope that this summer's busy travel season has legs beyond this Labor Day, which falls on the earliest possible date for the holiday. Added to that are travelers' lingering fears over terrorism, the continued conflict in Iraq and the imminent resumption of security fees on airplane tickets.
"It is going to be a bit of a long winter," said John P. Heimlich, managing director of economics for the Air Transport Association, the airline industry's trade group. 
That might sound overly bleak, given that airplanes have been crowded all summer. There are exceptions: the hotel industry, in particular, has hopes that the trend toward increased room revenue, which began earlier this summer, will continue.
Officials across the travel industry note that leisure and business travelers are waiting far longer than they did in the past to book trips, making demand difficult to forecast and creating some optimism that things might turn out better than expected.
But Mr. Heimlich said he thought the spurt of business this summer was partly a result of pent-up demand by travelers who put off winter and spring trips because of concerns over the war and SARS.
Over all, Mr. Heimlich said he saw no imminent rebound in business travel, which is off 15 percent from 2000, which is considered the industry's peak year. Corporations have already set their travel budgets for the rest of the year, and if anything, are likely to cut back even further if air fares rise, or if companies' balance sheets look precarious, he said.
"Businesses don't just fly more all of a sudden; there has tobe a need," Mr. Heimlich said.
Robert W. Mann, an industry analyst based in Port Washington, N.Y., said the airline industry generally sets its schedules two weeks after Labor Day. The last two years, the industry has made steep cuts in fall flights. "It's safe to say everyone is very concerned to see what happens after Sept. 15; that's the bellwether," Mr. Mann said.
As airlines determine their schedules, car-rental companies in turn will adjust their own fleets to match the expected demand. Craig R. Koch, chief executive at the Hertz Corporation, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, said he was guardedly optimistic. "I think the post-Labor Day season will be kind of flattish," Mr. Koch said in an interview this week.
He added that the leisure travel market, which generally fizzles after Labor Day weekend and does not pick up again until Thanksgiving, is showing some buoyancy.
Indeed, revenue per available room, a crucial measure in the industry, has risen in eight of the last nine weeks, according to Jan Freitag of Smith Travel Research. "That is a very positive sign coming out of the third quarter and heading into the fourth," he said.
Michael J. Rietbrock, an analyst with Smith Barney, said that the industry's tight supply of rooms before the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks and the halt to construction afterwards, could mean that prices would rise even more should demand be stronger. "We believe the stage is being set for a sustained recovery in the hotel business," Mr. Rietbrock said.
Sue A. Brush, senior vice president of Westin Hotels and Resorts North America, a unit of Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc., was also optimistic about the outlook for corporate travel. Westin's revenues are up 2 percent in the first seven months of this year compared with the same period in 2002, she said, and she added that she expected business bookings to pick up this fall, after two straight years of decline.
September and October are traditionally Westin's strongest months of the year for business travelers. Ms. Brush based her prediction on a pickup in bookings by individuals, and by small business groups.
But, free spending is not the state of affairs in either hotels or rental cars. "People are traveling more than they were last year, they just aren't spending as much," Mr. Freitag said. Instead, he said, they wait to snap up last-minute discounts from Web sites.
Back in the good old days of three years ago, Mr. Koch said, business travelers boarded planes and rented cars regardless of the cost. "If you're going to make a commercial trip, you're going to make a commercial trip," he said of that era. But in today's weak business climate, "unfortunately, they're not going to make commercial trips," he said.
There will be even less justification for last-minute flying after Oct. 1. That is when the government will reinstate a fee of $2.50 per flight segment to pay for security costs; that fee has been waived since June 1. That might not sound like much, but for corporations with thousands of employees on the road, the fees quickly mount. "Even $2 or $3 a ticket means you won't make your profit margins," Mr. Heimlich said.
Regardless, the airlines, hotels and car-rental companies are all responding to forecasts of tepid travel with fare sales to international destinations like Hong Kong and London, and discount rates for hotels in New York and Las Vegas.
Major airlines have also canceled "use it or lose it" policies" that rendered nonrefundable tickets worthless if not used on the originally intended flight. Generally, customers have a year's grace period in which to rebook their flights.
But Kevin P. Mitchell, the chairman of the Business Travel Coalition, which is based in Radnor, Pa., and represents business travelers and corporate travel departments, doubted that the gesture would assuage many passengers. 
"They knew it was bad," Mr. Mitchell said of the airlines, speaking by phone from his vacation home in Annapolis, Md., this week. "They knew their best customers were angry, but they thought it would all be forgotten when travel came back and business surged." 
"But it did nothing to address other problems in the system," he added, namely, that business fares remain too high in relation to those offered by low-fare airlines.
As a result, the low-fare airlines like Southwest Airlines and JetBlue Airways now account for 25 percent of domestic air travel, a figure that Mr. Mitchell said he expected to climb. The situation has driven customers "into the open arms of the low-fare carriers," he said.
Mr. Mann said, "Travel managers are now incentivized to continue the trend to low-fare carriers."
There is a silver lining of sorts for some in the travel industry. Mr. Koch at Hertz said low-fare airlines were helping his company pick up business that has been lost because of the drop in travel on major airlines. A decision by one of the low-fare alternatives to start service to a new market, or to expand service to an existing destination, has an almost instant impact on Hertz's business in that city, he said.
Car-rental companies can respond almost overnight, by ferrying more cars to those locations. The problem is, it is hard to tell where consumers will go and what they will book when they arrive because so many are putting off trips until the last minute.
In any case, Mr. Mann cautions against betting on a burst of spending. "The consumer who carried us through the economic downturn is totally tapped, both on consumer credit and home equity line extensions, and interest rates are headed back up," he said.
That leaves the industry particularly vulnerable if concern about terrorism causes people to stay home. Mr. Mitchell said he was especially concerned about the impact on the jittery corporate travel market, should an attack take place at home.
"If there were another incident on a commercial airliner in the United States, it's game over, lights out," he said. "It's beyond a disastrous fall. It's over."

U.S. Commander for Iraq Seeks More Muslim Troops
The top American commander for Iraq, Gen. John P. Abizaid, said there was no need for more American troops, but encouraged Muslim allies like Turkey and Pakistan to send peacekeepers. He also said training of a new Iraqi Army should be accelerated. A1

North Korea's Nuclear Threat
North Korea told diplomats from five other nations that it planned to declare formally that it has become a nuclear power and may test an atomic bomb in the near future to prove it, according to senior Bush administration officials. A9

Peruvian Death Toll Doubled
The Peruvian government-appointed truth commission said 69,000 people were killed or disappeared between 1980 and 2000, more than twice earlier estimates of the toll for the decades of war and dictatorship. A3

NATIONAL A12-17

Prosecutors Suspicious Of DNA Evidence
Prosecutors across the country acknowledge that DNA testing is reliable, but they have grown skeptical of its power to prove innocence in cases where there was other evidence of guilt. A1

Female Cadets Tell of Rapes
Nearly 12 percent of women who graduated from the United States Air Force Academy this year were the victims of rape or attempted rape during their four years at the academy, with the vast majority of them never reporting the incident to authorities, according to a survey by the Defense Department's inspector general. A12

Prison Policy Faulted
John J. Geoghan, the defrocked pedophile priest strangled in prison by another inmate, was confined in the same protective custody unit as his assailant largely because the Massachusetts Department of Correction has only two protective custody units, lawyers and experts familiar with the case say. A14

Michigan Revises Admissions
The University of Michigan unveiled a new admissions policy that preserves affirmative action but applies it less stringently to minority applicants. A12

New Voice for Unions
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced that it was creating a novel organization for nonunion workers who agree with the labor movement on many issues and want to campaign alongside labor on those issues. A16

E.P.A. Says It Lacks Authority
The Environmental Protection Agency said it did not have the legal authority to regulate carbon dioxide and emissions of other heat-trapping gases under the Clean Air Act. A17

White House Calls for Reviews
The White House budget office plans to require government agencies to employ independent experts to review the quality of scientific analyses used in developing regulations. A12

NEW YORK/REGION B1-8

Port Authority Releases Sept. 11 Transcripts
The Port Authority released more than 1,800 pages of transcribed radio transmissions from Sept. 11, 2001, much of them from dozens of people in and around the World Trade Center. The transmissions reflect the critical difficulties faced by those who survived the plane crashes, yet were unable to escape the buildings. A1

Free Tutoring Goes Unused
A vast majority of New York City children who were eligible for free tutoring last year under a new federal law never got the extra help, and critics say there are few signs of improvement this year. A1

States Challenge E.P.A. Shift
Environmental groups and state officials across the Northeast began preparing legal challenges after the Bush administration issued rules that will relax pollution-control regulations. B1

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Demand Is Up Sharply For Stomach Operations
Doctors and hospitals across the country are scrambling to satisfy the booming demand for surgery that shrinks the stomachs of severely obese people.
 Dozens of hospitals are adding operating suites for the procedure, called bariatric surgery. The procedures surged more than 40 percent last year, to 80,000. Spending for the operation is approaching $3 billion a year, about $25,000 for each procedure. Page A1. 

Ford Kicks Off F-150 Campaign
Ford Motor is starting an advertising campaign today for the debut of its completely redesigned F-150, the truck that makes up the bulk of the F-Series sales. Ford will spend more than $100 million over four to six months, its most expensive campaign ever. The F-Series pickups are the best-selling vehicle line of any kind in America and have been for more than two decades. Advertising. C4.

A New A.F.L.-C.I.O. Affiliate Group
Hoping to increase its political clout, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced that it was creating an organization for nonunion workers who agree with thelabor movement on many issues and want to campaign alongside labor. A12.

NASD Clamps Down on Brokers
NASD, formerly the National Association of Securities Dealers, proposed rules that would increase supervision of brokers who have a history of customer complaints. C5.

Phone Companies Appeal Rules
SBC Communications and other local telephone companies asked a court to overturn federal rules that give states more authority to decide if the phone companies must lease network components to rivals at discounts. C5.

Penthouse Is Formally Under Inquiry
Penthouse said that an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the company's previous financial statements had become a formal investigation. C4.

ArvinMeritor Extends Bid for Dana
ArvinMeritor extended its bid for a rival auto parts maker, the Dana Corporation, through Oct. 2, but did not raise its offer of $15 a share, or about $4.4 billion, for the company. C4.

Major Stock Gauges Move Higher
The Nasdaq composite index gained 18.05 points, or 1 percent, to 1,800.18, a 16-month high, in a subdued preholiday session. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed above the 1,000 level again, rising 6.05 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,002.84. The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 40.42 points, to 9,374.21. C5.

Fleet Buying Progress Financial
FleetBoston Financial has agreed to buy Progress Financial for $211 million to expand in Philadelphia as part of a plan to build its consumer business. C3.

Philippines Tries to Aid Its Currency
The Philippine central bank heeded a call by President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo to crack down on currency speculators and raised interest rates banks are paid to keep money at the central bank. World Business, Section W.

Developing the Dominican Republic
Grupo Punta Cana has spent 35 years investing in services in the Dominican Republic, creating a resort that is responsible for a quarter of the country's gross domestic product. World Business, Section W.

PUB-DATE: August 29, 2003
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 28

LENGTH: 5935 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary, especially over the Labor Day weekend, and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

"A.I.M. 23," Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse, at 165th Street, Morrisania, (718) 681-6000 (through Sept. 28). Every year the Bronx Museum puts on a show of work by participants in its Artists in the Marketplace program, which teaches emerging professionals how to manage and advance their careers. Highlights of this year's exhibition include Jeongtae Chae's optically vibrating arrangements of found objects, Joe Fig's miniature recreations of painters' work tables, Kate Gilmore's video of herself as she tries to bring order to chaos and Hidemi Sato's obliquely poetic grids of photographs depicting brightly colored restaurant and gas station signs against blue sky. Hours: Wednesdays, noon to 9 p.m.; Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students and 65+; free on Wednesdays (Ken Johnson).

* "THE AMERICAN EFFECT: GLOBAL PERSPECTIVES ON THE UNITED STATES, 1990-2003," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Oct. 12). Exploring ways that artists throughout the world react to the United States as a superpower, this show of documentary films, videos, installations, photographs, paintings and objects by 47 artists and filmmakers and 3 collaborative groups runs from sunny side up to deep despair. There are reflections on America's military might, its industrial clout, its treatment of minorities, its consumerism, its justice system, its marketing strategies, its religious evangelism, its celebrity worship and its interference with other governments. On the other hand, there are more positive expressions of admiration for the freedoms, the opportunities and the material achievements of a country unfettered by ancient traditions. A wacky installation by a French artist, Gilles Barbier, in the form of life-size figures, offers a wry take on the United States through its aging comic book heroes, viewed in the setting of a nursing home and in the last stages of decrepitude. In a very different key is a video projection dealing with the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in Dallas in 1963; the work, by a Serbian artist, Zoran Naskovski, is accompanied by a poignantly chanted tribute. The show has its weak spots but is provocative and visually compelling over all. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+ (Grace Glueck).

"ANSEL ADAMS AT 100," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Nov. 3). This exhibition of 113 of Adams's photographs, in celebration of the 100th anniversary of his birth, has been traveling around the world for two years. In these warehouse galleries it has a strangely random and homely feel. The photographs look small and lost. Maybe it's the setting. Maybe it's because the show, organized roughly thematically -- austere peaks, plants, peaks with plants, grand vistas, rocks -- doesn't have a clearly focused concept. Or maybe it's because the curator wanted to tamp down Adams's bombast and replace it with something quieter, smaller and subtler. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays to 7:45 p.m. Admission: $12; $8.50 for students and 65+ (Sarah Boxer).

* MAX BECKMANN, Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Sept. 29). Like Beckmann, this retrospective of that German genius is dense, frequently revelatory and exhausting: all that heavy-handed symbolism and claustrophobia. Beckmann can seem like a truculent master, glaring balefully at us from his self-portraits, disappointed by our moral turpitude. It is easy to get bogged down in the miasma of his obscure allusions. But he also puts brush to canvas with surprising tenderness. Color is luxurious, not garish. The humor is sly and black. Finally, he is unavoidably compelling. Hours and admission: See above. (Michael Kimmelman).

* "BLACK PRESIDENT: THE ART AND LEGACY OF FELA ANIKULAPO-KUTI," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 28). The Nigerian composer, musician and activist Fela Kuti (1938-1997) invented the musical style called Afrobeat, relentlessly assailed political corruption and repression in Africa and beyond through his records and performances and led a scandalous private life very publicly. This taut, vivacious exhibition is less about the man himself than about how 30 contemporary artists, most of them African or African-American, respond to his blazing, goading lodestar presence. Their reactions range from celebratory to critical, and few are simple, but his vision of a rejuvenated Africa still shines bright. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students, artists and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

"LOUISE BOURGEOIS: THE INSOMNIA DRAWINGS," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Sept. 21). In an eight-month run of sleep-short nights, the sculptor Louise Bourgeois turned the draggy hours to productive use, setting down thoughts, visions and memories that rose from the floor of her consciousness. What resulted are 250 drawings, considered one work by the artist, that range from simple to complex images: among them water, mazes, clocks, houses, abstract doodles, personal comments and fragments of texts. In short, a miscellany of clues to her inner and outer worlds, a scrap bag of images that may prompt her work. But while the dense, insistent visual environment they create is a bit of a phenomenon, the viewer does not really come away with a deeper understanding of the work, whose relationship to Ms. Bourgeois's deeply mined psyche is very evident in her realized art and in statements and interviews she has given over the years. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

"CHALLENGING TRADITION: WOMEN OF THE ACADEMY, 1826 TO 2003," National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Jan. 4). The National Academy's conservatism is reflected in this selection of works by women who enjoyed membership since its beginning in 1825. Fewearly works rise above decorous academicism, and modest gentility prevails into the 1930's, when Clare Leighton made exquisitely refined wood engravings. There's more excitement in works from the last 50 years. Anne Arnold's ruggedly chiseled portrait in wood of the excellent painter Lois Dodd, Catherine Murphy's acutely observed painting of a sumac forest and Susanna Coffey's intensely compacted painted self-portrait prove traditionalism doesn't have to stultify. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $4.50 for students (Johnson).

"SALVADOR DALI: DREAM OF VENUS," Queens Museum of Art, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 592-9700 (through Sept. 21). While images of the 1939 New York World's Fair in Queens remain ingrained in the American collective memory, one attraction, relegated to the "Amusement Zone," was largely forgotten until now: Dali's "Dream of Venus," a tacky Surrealist fun house with live, semi-nude women. This exhibition consists mainly of photographs that document the project from start to finish. Featuring the handsome, charismatic artist; his enigmatic wife, Gala; and lots of voluptuous, unclothed models, this show and its catalog tell a fascinating tale of idealism, opportunism, provocation and censorship. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 55+ (Johnson).

"DRAWN HOME: FRITZ VOGT'S RURAL AMERICA," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040 (through Sept. 21). During the last decade of the 19th century, Vogt, a German immigrant, supported himself by making portraits of homes in upstate New York. A homeless itinerant who preferred to sleep in his patrons' barns, Vogt made wonderfully lucid, formally ingenious drawings of farms with multiple outbuildings and of elaborately decorated Victorian showpieces with manicured grounds. The 26 drawings here tap into an American ethos that elevated domestic prosperity to something like a national religion. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Admission: $9; $7, students and 62+ (Johnson).

* "EGYPT REBORN: ART FOR ETERNITY," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (permanent installation). The second and final phase in the museum's reinstallation of its world-renowned holdings of ancient Egyptian art, this dazzling display rounds up more than 600 objects -- from king-and-queen-size monuments to tiny rings and amulets -- from the predynastic period to the 18th dynasty. Viewing it together with the first phase, which opened in 1993 and covers later Egyptian art, visitors will now be able to trace the entire course of this brilliant and complex civilization from its beginnings to its absorption by the Roman Empire in 30 B.C. The heart of the new installation is an introductory gallery that provides a wonderful summation, with a survey of sculptural styles and displays of weapons, pottery, cosmetics, jewelry, furniture and funerary arts. The adjacent galleries are devoted to an extensive chronological survey. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3, students and 62+ (Glueck).

"ENTERTAINING AMERICA: JEWS, MOVIES AND BROADCASTING," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Sept. 14). Marilyn Monroe's post-conversion mezuza and her music-box menorah are part of the lineup in this bustling roundup devoted to a century of Jewish presence in the entertainment world. A star-studded revue that takes the museum more than a step into show biz, it covers the 20th century from the early nickelodeons that preceded the Hollywood film industry to recent television manifestations like "Seinfeld," by way of film and video clips, audio tapes, photographs, posters and other artifacts. There is Al Jolson in "The Jazz Singer"; excerpts from Yiddish film and radio; Betty Boop, the sassy personification of a first-generation American Jewish girl from the Lower East Side; and pamphlets railing against Jewish prominence in the movie industry. There are also 10 "star shrines" that celebrate, mostly tongue in cheek, personalities like Sammy Davis Jr., Barbra Streisand and the silent film vamp Theda Bara (really a Jewish girl from Ohio). Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m.; Fridays, to 3 p.m. Admission: $10; $7.50, students and 65+ (Glueck).

* "FROM EXPRESSIONISM TO THE BAUHAUS: HIGHLIGHTS FROM THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART," Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200 (through Sept. 15). Borrowed from the Museum of Modern Art, this economical, powerfully resonant exhibition of German Modernist artworks from the first third of the 20th century includes Expressionist paintings by Ludwig Kirchner, Otto Mueller and Emil Nolde; mordantly satiric New Realist paintings by George Grosz and Otto Dix; and sumptuously elegant utilitarian objects by Marcel Breuer and Marianne Brandt. Hours: Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7 for students and 65+ (Johnson).

"FROM PICASSO TO POLLOCK: CLASSICS OF MODERN ART," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Sept. 28). This selective anthology of perennial in-house favorites in a major museum has much to be said for it. The bait is irresistible, the promised classics turn up here and there, and both the young and the not-so-young have a fine time on the ramps. In addition to fine examples by Kandinsky, Picasso, Leger, Chagall, Kokoschka and Malevich, there is an enormous piece in ceramic tiles by Joan Miro. Begun in 1965 and finished in 1967, it is largely in black-and-white, but every touch of color sings out. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $9 for students and 65+ (John Russell).

* "HENDRICK GOLTZIUS, DUTCH MASTER (1558-1617): DRAWINGS, PRINTS AND PAINTINGS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 7). Goltzius was one of the hottest of hotshot Dutch artists. He was particularly celebrated for his engravings, many of them mythological tableaus of pumped-up gods and pinup goddesses, rendered in the Mannerist way with flabbergasting elan. But he was also one of the great draftsmen of his age -- his landscape drawings prefigure Rembrandt and Ruisdael -- and became a virtuosic painter whose primary subject was bare human flesh: its texture, its color, its chemistry. To some eyes he remains strictly a period artist; to others he connects to the present in interesting ways. This Met show offers the raw materials for both reactions. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "GREAT WAVES: CHINESE THEMES IN THE ARTS OF KOREA AND JAPAN," Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue, at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 21). Basically a collection reinstallation with a novel mix-and-match approach, this show, spread over both the Chinese painting and Japanese galleries, traces the flow of influence from one culture to the other. Most of the action takes place in the Chinese galleries, where the art is arranged by motifs -- seascapes, landscapes, floral images -- that emerged early in China and circulated to Korea and Japan. The model proposed will provide grist for many scholarly mills in the future; the show itself is tremendous fun to look at. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

JOSE ANTONIO HERNANDEZ-DIEZ, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 21). Born in Venezuela in 1964, Mr. Hernandez-Diez is one of several urbane Latin American artists whose work might be described as a kind of vernacular conceptualism, a physically reductive, idea-rich art made from scraps of everyday consumerist life. His New Museum solo incorporates skateboards, household furniture, a stuffed pet dog, fake fingernails, baseball bats and photographs of designer sneakers, all put to unexpected uses. The results can be read in terms of local associations, but the real focus is on commonly shared experiences: appetite, rootlessness, faith and delusion, violence, the collective unconscious of globalized culture. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "LANDSCAPE OF MEMORY: THE ART OF MU XIN," Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 288-6400 (through Sept. 7.) The artist and writer Mu Xin, born into a wealthy aristocratic family in China, received a classical scholar's education and early exposure to Western culture. Targeted as a dissident during the Cultural Revolution, he was held in solitary confinement for 18 months, and he secretly wrote a series of first-person meditations now called "Prison Notes," which he carried out of jail sewn in his clothes. Under house arrest several years later, he executed a remarkable series of small landscape paintings in which traditional Chinese themes meet Leonardo da Vinci. The paintings and some of "Prison Notes" are brought together in this lean, penumbral exhibition, organized by the Yale University Art Gallery and the David and Alfred Smart Museum of Art at the University of Chicago. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

"LEGENDS OF OUR TIMES: NATIVE RANCHING AND RODEO LIFE ON THE PLAINS AND THE PLATEAU," National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3700 (through March 7). This lively account of man, woman and horse among the native people in Western reaches of the United States and Canada proves that a cowboy can be an Indian, and vice versa. The show depicts native peoples not as objects of exploitation by the white man but as ranchers, cowboys, entertainers and rodeo performers. It displays more than 700 objects -- saddles, bead and quill works, paintings, photographs, blankets, clothing, horse gear, hunting implements, roundup equipment, headdresses and other ceremonial garb -- from the 18th century to now. At least half of this huge show provides an engaging and comprehensive account of rodeo, but nonrodeo fans will probably have more fun with the bedazzlement of objects depicting the more traditional side of American Indian life. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. Free (Glueck).

"MATERIAL DIFFERENCES: ART AND IDENTITY IN AFRICA," Museum for African Art, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700 (through October). Part Art Methods 101, part Advanced Connoisseurship, this handsome, thoughtful show examines the potent connection between matter and meaning in diverse African cultures and shows them to be organically connected. The material is spiritual in these cultures, and the show's 130 mostly ceremonial objects, arranged strictly according to materials and techniques, reflect the power of that belief. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

"NOGUCHI -- THE BOLLINGEN JOURNEY: PHOTOGRAPHS AND DRAWINGS, 1949-1956," Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum (temporary space), 36-01 43rd Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens, (718) 204-7088 (through Oct. 13). More than 100 photographs and drawings recreate Noguchi's travels from 1949 to 1956, on a grant from the Bollingen Foundation. The project was for an ambitious book (never completed) on the spaces and structures -- religious, monumental, classical and communal -- of familiar as well as less-documented societies. Besides providing an elegant travelogue, the photographs give some idea of the many sources that Noguchi drew on for his work. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 65+ (Glueck)

"PULP ART: VAMPS, VILLAINS AND VICTORS FROM THE ROBERT LESSER COLLECTION," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Oct. 19). This murky exhibition showcases the small, gaudy, largely unappreciated paintings commissioned for the covers of the pulp magazines that ruled the newsstands between the wars. While ultimately a bit repetitious, their overheated depictions of sharp-jawed heroes, compromised heroines and various human and nonhuman villains highlight talents like George Rozen and Paul R. Frank. They also give vent to the dark, violent, libidinous underbelly of the American psyche, to the same degree that Norman Rockwell's paintings bless its wholesome, repressed, preternaturally sunny side. The show is essential viewing for anyone interested in popular culture past or present. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

"REMEMBERING THE FORGOTTEN ONES: MILTON ROGOVIN," New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, (212) 873-3400 (through Oct. 12). Mr. Rogovin, who is 93, has been photographing the residents of Buffalo's Lower West Side, a largely black, Latino and immigrant neighborhood, since the 1950's. Wonderful images have emerged: a benignly smiling elderly man pushing a baby in a carriage; alert kids dressed in cool street styles; a teenage mother standing with her infant in front of a wall bearing the chalk-written words "I love you God." At regular intervals, Mr. Rogovin has rephotographed some of his original subjects, and he displays the updates in four-picture sequences that he calls quartets. In them, couples marry and have families; change homes, partners and eras; gain weight, gain perspective, disappear. Sad, traumatic or sweet, these visual versions of oral history are the highlight of the show. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for students and 65+ (Cotter).

"USDESIGN 1975-2000," Museum of Arts & Design, 40 West 53rd Street, (212) 956-3535 (through Nov. 2). This survey of objects designed during the 20th century's last quarter is disappointing, partly because few of the products on view are very interesting to look at and partly because it sheds so little light on a field that has expanded in a mind-boggling variety of directions in recent years. Focused mainly on consumer goods like chairs, clocks, lamps, teapots, telephones, sneakers, ski boots, roller blades, sunglasses and computers, it has the feel of an outmoded department store. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $8; $5 for students and 65+ (Johnson).

"WILLEM VAN TETRODE: BRONZE SCULPTURES OF THE RENAISSANCE," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Sept. 7). This exhibition introduces a neglected Dutch artist who flourished amid the cultural ferment of 16th-century Italy, when the rediscoveries of monumental Classical marbles helped fuel a passion for mythological themes, the rise of private collecting and a new sense of physical and emotional drama in sculpture. Prodigiously talented, van Tetrode navigated his own path between Classicism and Mannerism with beautifully detailed bronzes, most notably a splendidly muscled and bearded Hercules dispatching various labors with violent panache. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $12; $5 for students; $8 for 62+ (Smith).

"VIETNAM: JOURNEYS OF BODY, MIND AND SPIRIT," American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, (212) 769-5100 (through Jan. 4). For many Americans who came of age before or during the 1960's, Vietnam was the name of a place you didn't want to go to. Even today the prevailing impression of this part of Southeast Asia seems to be a composite of remembered news clips and scenes from "Apocalypse Now." More than a quarter-century after the war, the image is due for revision, and that is the basic idea behind this show, a lavishly illustrated anthropological field trip through Vietnam today. Using objects, videos and photographs, it examines popular traditions associated with marriage, death and religion, often to vivid effect, in a lively, serpentine installation. And even with many important political and social questions left unasked and unanswered, there is a wealth of information here. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. Admission: $12; $9, students and 60+ (Cotter).

Galleries: SoHo

* HELMUT FEDERLE, "Works on Paper," Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through Sept. 13). From the mid-1970's to the late 1990's, the Swiss-born painter Helmut Federle extended his imagery from geometricized but lush mountain peaks to the freest of signs and markings. The 200 drawings on view here trace his progress. Although the work remains in a highly reductive geometricized mode, it is sometimes quirkily dreamy and sensuous, with more than a touch of whimsy. In these 200 drawings, which gain strength from being grouped together, Mr. Federle's many and varied passes at the paper range from the precise scientific textbook rendering "Constellation" (1983) to more relaxed and painterly grids like "Untitled" (1992), in which eroded bright blue bands are dragged across a white ground. He is a great performer; even his most fragmentary wisps hold the eye (Glueck).

Galleries: Chelsea

"BOYS OF SUMMER," ClampArt, 531 West 25th Street, (646) 230-0020 (tomorrow through Sept. 6). If you like to look at men, and you're passing by, stop in. Standing out among the crowd of pictures by more than two dozen photographers are "Bruce in His Car," a 1981 portrait of a skinny bohemian in his big red convertible by Nan Goldin; a beefy, shirtless young football player celebrating with his team, by Brian Finke; men in leather, by Barbara Nitke; and, by Malerie Marder, a large color image of a mixed group of naked people relaxing in a California bathhouse (Johnson).

* "IN FULL VIEW," Andrea Rosen, 525 West 24th Street, (212) 627-6000 (through Sept. 13). A show that invites visitors on a pluralistic treasure hunt for 18 artworks that tease one's limits of visual perception. Look for Christopher Chiappa's Ford Taurus gas-tank door built into the wall; Maurizio Cattelan's roosting stuffed pigeons; Vincent Shine's tiny, gold Brancusian wasp; Jim Hodges's jewelry-chain spider web; and Charles Ray's classic "Rotating Disc" (Johnson).

ANDREI MOLODKIN, Kashya Hildebrand, 531-539 West 25th Street, (212) 366-5757 (Tuesday through Sept. 13). This skillful Russian draftsman has a heavy-handed way with popular and political symbols. He draws giant parodies of "I Love N.Y." or "I Love Sex" bumper stickers, replacing the valentine heart with anatomically accurate skulls. Also on view is a double portrait of Lenin and Stalin. What's most interesting is not the imagery but how these enormous drawings are made: entirely with a blue ballpoint pen (Johnson).

"SPLIT," Sandra Gering, 534 West 22nd Street, (646) 336-7183 (through Sept. 6). The best thing in this six-person show is Xavier Veilhan's bigger-than-life skeleton woven in wicker; it slouches casually in a corner of the gallery, a marvel of exotic faux-folk art. Note, too, a dense mix of cartoon characters and abstract patterning painted collaboratively in gouache by Christian Schumann and Gary Panter (Johnson).

"THIS IS LAGOS: YABIS NIGHT, MUSIC AND FELA," Skoto, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 352-8058 (through Sept. 13). If you crave a second fix of the charismatic Nigerian musician Fela Anikulapo-Kuti after seeing "Black President" at the New Museum, Skoto is the place to go. Much of this gallery's fine summer show is devoted to vivid pictures of Fela by the Nigerian photographer Femi Bankole Osunla, who was part of Fela's inner circle from the early 1970's to the musician's death from AIDS in 1997. This work is complemented by a handsome series of color images of Africa by the American photographer Howard T. Cash, two heads sculptured by Osaretin Ighile and an alterlike installation by the young American artist Sol Sax (Cotter).

"VACATION," Spike, 547 West 20th Street, (212) 627-4100 (through Sept. 20). Innocence and experience collide in the works of Norm Magnusson, who outlines juvenile, coloring-book-style images over gridded fields of pages from pointedly selected books. Jesus offering guidance to a little boy is drawn over pages from Bulfinch's "Mythology," for example, and paper-doll clothes over "Lolita." Also on view: Buck Henri's engaging photographs of exotic dancers, old cars, mannequins, small-town parades and other subjects; Alan Schmer's illustrative paintings of farm animals; and Melissa Stern's pedestal-size figurative sculptures that blend Surrealism and primitivism (Johnson).

Other Galleries

"MIRACLE IN THE SCRAP HEAP: THE SCULPTURE OF RICHARD STANKIEWICZ," AXA Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, (212) 554-4818 (through Sept. 25). Welded together from scrap metal, Mr. Stankiewicz's slyly figurative semi-abstract sculptures from the mid-1950's were early warning signs that Abstract Expressionism was losing traction, and more worldly subjects, materials and ideas were bubbling up all around. His ingeniously composed works lived up to titles like "Kabuki Dancer," "Urchin," "Marionette," "Middle-Aged Couple" and "Family Portrait" with the spine-tingling accuracy of unusually art-savvy cartoons. They expanded upon Cubism, rebuked the prevailing lugubriousness of postwar sculpture and predicted many aspects of Pop and Minimalism. But they were too respectful of tradition to withstand the double-barreled onslaught of those movements. Organized by the Addision Gallery of American Art at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., this thoughtful show is the first Stankiewicz retrospective in New York. His penchant for compositional complexity, cartoonish figuration and the calculated two-timing of the abstract and the representational seem unusually pertinent and full of possibility (Smith).

Last Chance

"ART CHANTRY: GREATEST HITS, VOL. 1," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-24 Jackson Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Sunday). The argument against graphic design as an art form receives its latest drubbing in this revelatory survey, organized by Robert Nikas and presenting more than 300 posters and album covers by Mr. Chantry, the Seattle-based designer and art director. Dating from the late 1970's to the present, these works capture much of the vitality of that city's underground music and theater scene while defining a maverick sensibility whose inventive, low-tech production values and polymorphous recycling of images add a chapter of their own to the history of appropriation art. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2 for students and 62+ (Smith).

"CUBA ON THE VERGE: AN ISLAND IN TRANSITION," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000 (through Sunday). Is it possible for anyone to photograph Cuba without some sort of romance creeping in? The concept behind this show of Cuban, Cuban-American and American photographers was to eschew "cliched images of vintage American cars and other remnants of a prerevolutionary era" and instead to "convey Cuba present," as the show's guest curator, Terry McCoy, writes in the catalog. But some of the photographs suggest that even as Cuba sinks deeper into poverty, ruin and prostitution, the romance of faded beauty and glamorous revolution won't go away. The most refreshing shots are those in which subjects confront the camera and the fantasy. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7, students and 62+ (Boxer).

* "DREAMING IN PICTURES: THE PHOTOGRAPHY OF LEWIS CARROLL," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000 (through Sunday). A photograph is at least as much a looking glass as it is a window. We see in it our own reflections and obsessions. A post-Freudian world has inevitably come to see C. L. Dodgson's photographs through the looking glass of his alter ego, Lewis Carroll. This provocative show tries to put Dodgson's pictures back in their context, to stress that we have lost touch with Victorian conventions, which Dodgson largely obeyed when he photographed little girls. Childhood to Victorians represented, as the show's curator puts it, an "alternate reality, a metaphysical state of preknowledge." Dodgson, he adds, "could pose his charges in adult roles, give them guns, daggers and exotic costumes, even portray them as odalisques and half-dressed waifs, because he and most of his audience believed so emphatically in their total insulation from the implications of such postures." These presentations do not so much underscore the latent sexuality of the child (as we post-Freudians would have it) as they do an obvious lack of it. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

TED FAIERS, "Paintings From the 1950's," Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through today). Indian Space painting was a mid-20th-century American movement that mixed Cubist abstraction with American Indian-style patterns and pictographs. Faiers's exercises in that now dimly remembered style have at best an appealing jazziness and chromatic radiance. There is something ultimately silly, though, about the idea of the sophisticated urbanite getting in touch with his inner shaman (Johnson).

* "HALF AIR," Marianne Boesky, 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 680-9889 (through today). Everything in this fascinating reliquary of a show looks as if it were exhumed from some moldy basement. It includes enigmatic, semi-abstract symbolist paintings by Forrest Bess; mesmerizing, diagrammatic linear compositions by Genn Branca; videos of the performance artist Charlemagne Palestine whipping himself into Dionysian frenzies; snapshots documenting the demimonde of the performance artist Jack Smith; and scenes from a Wooster Group film featuring the seaside antics of cross-dressed nuns (Johnson).

* "RAINING ELEPHANTS," Little Cakes Little Gallery, 240 East Fourth Street, Apt. 1D, East Village, (212) 979-9736 (through Sunday). This new apartment gallery has opened with a delightful show of work by the Pennsylvania artist Ed Wilcox and the Virginia collective Dearraindrop. Mr. Wilcox, who is in a band, works with several mediums, including painting, collage, sculpture and copying machines, with which he conjurs finely wrought, hallucinatory cartoon images. Dearraindrop specializes in what might be called collages of collages, incrementally covering the walls of the gallery with patches of fabric, cut paper, photographs, record album covers and paint. There is a library's worth of free-associational material here. Best of all, though, is Dearraindrop's rapid-fire, eye-tickling video, a time capsule of pop culture put through a shredder. The gallery is open Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 7 p.m. (Cotter).

"SITE AND INSIGHT: AN ASSEMBLAGE OF ARTISTS," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Sunday). Agnes Gund, former president of the Museum of Modern Art, a major collector and a longtime supporter of the arts, is the curator of a generally bland show of works by 15 artists she has followed over the years. Highlights include Ellen Phelan's elegant, soft-
focus landscape paintings; gnarly junk assemblages by Bruce Conner and Arthur Simms; Peter Campus's hypnotic, semi-abstracted video landscapes; and Jim Hodges's enormous curtain made of hundreds of stitched-together fake flowers. Hours and admission: See above (Johnson).

"ANDY WARHOL: SCREEN TESTS," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Monday). From 1964 to 1966, Warhol shot 500 short, silent black-and-white films of artists, musicians, actors, writers, filmmakers, models, curators, celebrities and hangers-on at the Factory. The Modern has restored 277 of these screen tests, representing about 34 hours of watching time, and now 28 of the films are being shown continuously on six screens. The subjects include Baby Jane Holzer, Salvador Dali, James Rosenquist, Dennis Hopper, Cass Elliott and Susan Sontag, but they are of variable interest. By shooting the films at one speed and playing them more slowly, Warhol exposedthe mechanics of discomposure and charisma. Some people are fascinating as they lose charisma; others are not. It has nothing to do with handsomeness, histrionics, coolness, slimness, trying or giving up. The typology of charisma is as elusive as the typology of criminality. Hours and admission: See above (Boxer).

HEADLINE: North Korea Says It May Test an A-Bomb 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN with DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Friday, Aug. 29 

 BODY:
North Korea told diplomats from five other nations on Thursday that it planned to declare formally that it has become a nuclear power and may test an atomic bomb in the near future to prove it, according to senior Bush administration officials.
 The statement by Kim Yong Il, North Korea's deputy foreign minister, appeared to sharply contradict the spirit of the six-party talks organized by China, North Korea's closest ally and leading aid donor, and may buttress the contention of hard-liners in the Bush administration that the reclusive Communist government has no intention of reaching a verifiable agreement to dismantle its nuclear program. 
 Even so, China prodded the United States, North Korea, South Korea, Russia and Japan, the participants in the talks that concluded here this afternoon, to agree to another round within two months, China's state media said.
Though there was no firm date set for future talks, the parties involved had said that they would consider an agreement to continue a dialogue a significant step, given the often volatile relations between North Korea and the United States. 
Asian diplomats described Thursday's meeting in less negative terms than did American officials, who revealed some details of the Beijing meetings to reporters in Washington on Thursday. These diplomats said the meeting was all along intended as a forum for parties to present negotiating positions, not to fully resolve differences.
North Korea has often made bellicose statements at negotiating sessions. In April, in its last meeting with the United States, a North Korean diplomat told James A. Kelly, then and now the head of the American negotiating team, that it had nuclear weapons and was moving quickly to develop more by extracting plutonium from spent nuclear fuel rods.
Administration officials cautioned that they had not yet seen a word-by-word translation of what the North Koreans said on Thursday, so they could not assess how much it went beyond the threats the North has issued in the past.
"Maybe they are bluffing, but if so, it raises the bluff to a new level," a senior official in Washington said.
The officials also said the statement by North Korea was perplexing because it is risky to publicize a nuclear test in advance, given the real chance that the test might fail.
In public, the White House insisted that it was unfazed by the North's action, calling it yet another effort by to increase pressure on President Bush through bluster and threats.
"North Korea has a long history of making inflammatory comments that serve to isolate it from the rest of the world," said Claire Buchan, a White House spokeswoman, speaking in Crawford, Tex. She said Mr. Bush had not backed away from his commitment that the United States would never tolerate a nuclear North.
Administration officials have not said how they would react to a nuclear test, which would show that North Korea has the ability to turn its nuclear technology into working weapons -- a step one intelligence analyst said recently was "something the North Koreans themselves probably aren't sure they can do."
But if North Korea follows through on its threat and conducts a nuclear explosion, that would almost certainly produce a serious escalation of the crisis and result in a breakdown of the current diplomatic overture.
A nuclear test could prompt the United States to seek a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning North Korea, opening the door to sanctions. North Korean officials have said they would consider sanctions an act of war.
Mr. Kim's comments came on the second day of discussions here at Diaoyutai state guest house, where representatives of the six nations were asked by China to respond to proposals put forward by other parties on Wednesday.
Mr. Kim, apparently responding to Mr. Kelly's rejection of the North's proposal to sign a nonaggression pact before it admits nuclear inspectors and scraps its nuclear program, accused the United States of refusing to abandon its hostile policy toward his country. 
Mr. Kim then said that the North intended to declare formally that it has nuclear weapons, and the ability to deliver them, and that it plans to test them, according to officials in Washington who were briefed on the talks by Mr. Kelly.
When negotiators from Russia and Japan sought to look for common ground between American and North Korean positions, Mr. Kim accused diplomats from those two countries of lying on instructions from the United States, according to Bush administration officials.
Some Bush administration officials have been saying for months that North Korea appears set on becoming a nuclear power and that a tight regime of sanctions and multilateral pressure, or even military action, may be necessary to prevent that from happening. But American officials had also supported the current talks because they view the discussions as a chance to put collective pressure on the North.
China, South Korea and Russia worked throughout the talks to balance American demands for a complete and verifiable end to North Korea's nuclear program with the North's call for a nonaggression treaty with Washington and for economic aid for its strapped economy.
A Chinese foreign policy expert informed about China's strategy at the talks said Beijing proposed a four-point declaration stating that all sides agree that the Korean peninsula should remain nuclear free, that the issue must be resolved peacefully, that North Korea's security concerns must be addressed, and that talks should be continued in the near future, he said.
The final statement appeared to fall short of that goal, with the various sides saying that they had a frank exchange of views and would continue to discuss the problem.

HEADLINE: Kerry Advocates Repealing Some Tax Cuts 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.H., Aug. 28 

 BODY:
Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts called today for rolling back some of President Bush's tax cuts to finance programs to reduce state taxes and encourage job creation.
 In a clear reference to his rival Howard Dean, Mr. Kerry said Democrats who were pressing to repeal all the tax cuts were peddling "rejected, old-style policies" that would cost middle-class families thousands of dollars a year. 
 Mr. Kerry said some Democrats "are so angry at George Bush and his unfair tax cuts" that they would repeal them entirely, adding $2,000 to the tax burden of a family offour -- "the hard-working, middle-class Americans who have borne the brunt of the Bush bust." 
Dr. Dean and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri are the only Democratic candidates who advocate completely undoing the Bush tax cuts. Mr. Kerry said they should be repealed only for people making more than $200,000 a year.
Mr. Kerry's speech at the University of New Hampshire, in which he spelled out his economic plan, came midway through a weeklong publicity push that is to culminate next week in a two-day announcement tour in which his advisers hope to seize the momentum from Dr. Dean.
A spokeswoman for Dr. Dean, Tricia Enright, responded by saying that "politicians in Washington" -- including senators, presumably -- had driven the country into debt "during both Bush recessions," while Dr. Dean was "balancing budgets" as governor of Vermont. "Some may say that's old-style politics," she added. "Howard Dean calls it old-fashioned common sense."
Mr. Gephardt said in a statement that his health care plan would give middle-class families $2,000 or more. "The challenges in front of our country require bold, ambitious solutions, not timid proposals that simply nibble around the edges," he said.
In his speech, Mr. Kerry called for tens of billions of dollars in new federal aid to states, college students and companies that hire more workers. He said the federal government was overspending at a rate of $1 billion a day, and vowed to restore pay-as-you-go fiscal discipline to Washington and cut the budget deficit in half in four years.
"When it comes to creating opportunity, restoring fiscal discipline, and putting values back into our economy, and preparing for the jobs of the future, George Bush has not lifted a finger," Mr. Kerry said. "I intend to move mountains."
Missing from Mr. Kerry's plan was the "tax holiday" he had been promoting as recently as June, which would have given workers an exemption from payroll tax on the first $10,000 of income. His advisers said the passage of the president's tax package had made it more sensible to modify the Bush tax cut as an economic stimulus.
Mr. Kerry said his partial repeal of the Bush tax cuts, along with cost-cutting measures like reducing the number of political appointees and eliminating their bonuses, would save $40 million. He proposed using $25 billion of that in his first two years as a bailout to cash-strapped states that would otherwise have to raise taxes or cut spending.
Calling Mr. Bush the "job-loss president," Mr. Kerry said Americans were being put out of work at a rate of more than two a minute. He called for a new incentive to manufacturers to expand in the United States, offering to refund the first two years of payroll taxes paid on any new employees. And he said he would expand the federal Hope scholarship to provide a tax credit of up to $2,500 a year for all four years of college tuition.
Some of what Mr. Kerry proposed today was a repackaging of legislation he and others in Congress have supported for years, like a tax incentive for manufacturers that expand their domestic production rather than move jobs overseas.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 30, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about a call by Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, to repeal some of President Bush's tax cuts misstated the amount he said would be saved by the rollback and other suggested cost-saving measures. It is $40 billion, not $40 million.
