SECTION: Section 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 1132 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey; 
Cities Outpace Suburbs in Difficult Office Market

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
WHILE the office real estate market in northern New Jersey has taken a lengthy beating in both cities and suburbs, the cities -- particularly Newark -- have emerged as tougher survivors of hard economic times, most assessments show.
 Newark's office vacancy rate now stands at 13 to 14 percent, according to various real estate company reports and broker estimates. In suburban Parsippany, by comparison, the vacancy rate has been more than 20 percent for more than two years, decreasing a percentage point in the second quarter of 2003, to 22.3 percent, according to Cushman & Wakefield's numbers. 
 In other suburban pockets, perhaps most notably the one along the northwestern section of Route 78 -- where the telecommunications industry used to loom large -- the vacancy rate is close to 30 percent, several market specialists said. 
"This could only look good," one said, "next to the availability along Route 78 in Somerset County." On a stretch of that Interstate highway in central New Jersey, Cushman said, the vacancy rate was 36.1 percent at midyear.
"It all depends on what the pillars of a marketplace are," said Dudley Ryan, a senior vice president of Trammell Crow. "Route 78 was more dependent upon the telecommunications-related industries, so they were hurt more when that industry fell down. Newark has been the strongest market through the recession because its pillars are government, law and insurance -- which are not as vulnerable to the whims of the economy."
Right now, though, there are signs that both urban and suburban office markets are picking up -- each in its own way.
Charles Ramat, who is president of the Kushner Companies, which owns office properties in Newark and several suburban markets, said there had been a "surge in customers and renting" in both markets. 
Kushner is trying to attract a major law firm for a 50,000-square-foot space in its refurbished Military Park building in Newark, where a number of small firms, foundations and title companies are already ensconced. In Florham Park, Kushner has almost completed assembling Columbia Corporate Center, a five-building office parkcampus made up of two buildings it owned for several years, two it recently acquired and one it is building.
"There has been a definite increase in traffic the last several months, clientele looking at the buildings," Mr. Ramat said. "Traffic is an important factor."
Jeffrey L. Heller, a senior director at Cushman, said there were suddenly many more customers shopping for office space in various markets at what is ordinarily a slow time of year. "I manage a team of six guys, and it's beginning to affect our lifestyle," he quipped, "eating into our vacation time." 
His counterpart at CB Richard Ellis, Thomas Reilly, talked about the potential for a "healthy drop" in the overall vacancy rate by the end of the third quarter. He also mentioned the possibility of plugging two capacious holes -- one in Jersey City amid the state's biggest and busiest office market on the Hudson waterfront, and the other in Basking Ridge at the sprawling former AT&T complex, now owned by Pfizer.
In Jersey City, much broker speculation is focused on a possible match between the 40-story, 1.5-million-square-foot Goldman Sachs building going up on Hudson Street, and a concern currently looking for a million square feet: the Mellon Financial Group.
Mellon, now spread out in nine buildings in six communities in northern New Jersey, seeks to consolidate its human resources group into one building with good commuter access for 4,000 employees. Goldman Sachs has said that it plans to occupy the riverfront building at the old Colgate site, but real estate analysts predict it will use only a fraction of the space.
As for the 2.7-million-square-foot Basking Ridge complex, speculation is rife among brokers that Pfizer has decided to stop marketing and use the space itself, so-called backfilling. Pfizer obtained the property when it acquired Pharmacia earlier this year; Pharmacia bought the seven-building, 140-acre complex from AT&T just weeks before being acquired.
Mr. Ryan said he understood that the huge space -- which pushes up the vacancy rate for the entire area -- was off the market.
Mr. Reilly said: "I think there is a distinct possibility that is what could happen. If the rumors of Pfizer backfilling and Mellon taking one million square feet at Goldman Sachs are true, that makes the market a lot healthier in one whack."
Several brokers mentioned positive developments in Parsippany -- northern Jersey's third-largest market after the Hudson waterfront and Newark -- in the last two months after a relatively stagnant first half. Pfizer took two blocks of space, leasing an office at Morris Corporate Center IV and subleasing space at 5 Woodhollow Drive that American Express has been marketing since returning to Manhattan after using the Parsippany space in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks.
The largest deal in Parsippany so far this year involved Reckitt Benckiser, a British maker of household cleaning and speciality food products, which decided to relocate its North American headquarters from Wayne, N.J., and to sublet 139,538 square feet from Aventis at Morris Corporate Center IV. Also in that building, Aventis continued to backfill, deciding to use an additional 88,462 square feet -- and leaving only 42,000 square feet vacant in the building.
The vast quantities of sublease space that became available with the telecommunications bust that began two years ago decimated Parsippany's office market, Mr. Heller of Cushman said. Offices of any size, many fully furnished, laden with amenities and telecommunications hookups, are widely available for sublet from companies ready to offer various concessions to unload space that will otherwise sit empty. 
COMPANIES offering blocks of sublet space of more than 50,000 square feet in Morris County, where Parsippany is situated, include Lucent, Cherry Road Technologies, Accenture, Tycom, Chubb and Wyeth. 
But sublease space is beginning to decline in Parsippany, according to Cushman's most recent quarterly report, with many original leases expiring this year and next, and responsibility reverting to the landlord. Currently, sublease space accounts for 39 percent of the available space, down from 47 percent at the end of 2002. 
Asking rental rates are beginning to decline, Cushman's second-quarter report said. Class A office rental rates declined $1 per square foot, falling below $30 per square foot annually for the first time since 1999.
In Newark, asking rents held steady at about $33 per square foot at midyear, Cushman reported. Leasing activity was up, primarily because of expansion by law firms. The Internal Revenue Service also renewed its lease of 42,687 square feet at One Newark Center.

HEADLINE: School Bells Ring In Changes 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
HOGWARTS will soon be in session.
 The new four-level middle school at Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn Heights, which is to open on Sept. 8, has been built within the prickly Gothic 19th-century shell of a former Anglican church. Some classrooms look out on to multicusped tracery windows through a screen of sweeping timber arches. The flexible teaching space on the top level soars to a pointed arch 47 feet high. 
 Corridors weave in and out of ornament-encrusted cast-iron columns, whose floral capitals are almost close enough to touch. Stained-glass seraphim gaze over a staircase from a giant rose window. No wonder readers of Harry Potter already call it Hogwarts. (Indeed, some teachers and administrators dressed up as wizards last May to celebrate the opening of the dining hall and faculty lounge in the old parish house next door.) 
Packer's $23 million project may be the most unusual recent renovation of a landmark or landmark-quality school building, but it is not the only one. As students return to class around New York City, they will find any number of schools looking bigger and fresher than they have in years.
Village Community School has almost doubled in size by grafting a complementary new structure to its 19th-century home at 272 West 10th Street. The Spence School has turned a landmark mansion at 56 East 93rd Street into its new lower school, burrowing deep into bedrock -- as noise-bedeviled neighbors can attest -- to create a subterranean gymnasium.
All three projects were financed in part through tax-exempt bonds issued by the city's Industrial Development Agency, which -- despite its name -- extends construction and renovation assistance to certain nonprofit corporations, including private elementary and secondary schools, for job creation or retention. Since 1990, it has issued more than $400 million in bonds on behalf of more than 30 private schools, attended by some 17,000 students, that employ more than 4,600 people.
Among public schools, the School of the Future at Lexington Avenue and 22nd Street has emerged from a $4.6 million renovation of its terra-cotta facade, part of a larger initiative by the School Construction Authority. "There have been two major components of the previous capital plans," said E. Bruce Barrett, vice president for architecture and engineering at the authority. "One is new seats and the other is exterior renovation. You've got to get the buildings watertight."
While "Future" is an apt name for the 13-year-old college-preparatory program in which about 600 students are enrolled, it is an incongruous designation for the building, an 86-year-old structure designed by C. B. J. Snyder in the Collegiate Gothic style. As the ornate letters on one facade proclaim, this was originally the Manhattan Trade School for Girls. At 10 stories, it is still one of the tallest school buildings in the city.
Responding to reports of spalling terra cotta, the authority undertook a detailed analysis of the facade, working with engineers from Robert Silman Associates and a company called GBG of Cambridge, England. The English company specializes in nondestructive inspection techniques, including thermal images that reveal the condition of masonry by graphically displaying its temperature.
About 20 percent of the terra cotta -- including the pilasters and the quatrefoil parapet -- was replaced, said Parmesh Nizambad, a structural engineer at theauthority. The building is now free of scaffolding for the first time in three years.
IN Brooklyn, another Gothic structure recently liberated from scaffolding is the former St. Ann's Episcopal Church at Clinton and Livingston Streets, which stands at one end of Packer's L-shaped complex.
Designed by James Renwick Jr., St. Ann's Church and adjacent parish house were purchased by Packer in 1969. Under a renovation designed by Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates, they have now been fully integrated with the other buildings through a glass-walled atrium constructed in the crook of the L.
Though the Victorian Gothic church looks largely unchanged on the outside -- except for the replacement of many stained-glass windows by clear, diamond-patterned panes -- it is now a kind of structural shell for an entirely new classroom structure that fills much of the original nave.
The idea of inserting a modern building into a 134-year-old church was so daunting that the architect, Hugh Hardy, cheerfully confessed this month that he did not want to take on the project at first. "Do you know how many code issues there are?" he asked. He credited Pamela J. Loeffelman, formerly in his firm (now at Perkins Eastman), with having persuaded him to try, and Packer with having endorsed the solution.
"You couldn't get any old client to do this," Mr. Hardy said.
Robert Silman Associates served as structural engineers and the Lehr Construction Corporation as construction manager, working with HRH Construction.
Packer, which has 935 students from preschool through the 12th grade, is financing the project through a $13 million Industrial Development Agency bond issue and a $10 million capital campaign. "We've crossed the finish line," Lynn B. Bunis, the development director and a Packer parent, said last week. In fact, she said, the campaign raised slightly more than $11 million.
In laying out the new middle school, the first impulse would have been to place the classrooms against exterior windows, with a corridor through the middle. The architects proposed instead that the classrooms be stacked within the nave, allowing the flanking aisles to serve as circulation areas and as light courts. "We filled up the middle and left the outside free, so you get a sense of the whole," Mr. Hardy said. 
The new 20,000-square-foot classroom stack is faced in etched mirror glass, which softly reflects the dull yellow of the surrounding walls. There is an additional 8,000 square feet of new space in the basement.
To open up the side aisles, the balconies were removed. And to increase the amount of daylight reaching the interior, many of the stained-glass windows were taken out. These were placed at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, N.Y., and St. Joseph's University in Philadelphia, according to Levien & Company, which served as Packer's representative on the job. The windows that remained were restored by Clerkin Higgins Stained Glass Inc.
More than 80 pews have been refurbished and will be placed throughout the school as places for the students to hang out, said Andrei S. Harwell, the project architect. Most of the religious iconography was removed but two Christian monograms -- iota-eta-sigma, a reference to Jesus, and alpha-omega -- remain in the rose window. "It was an Episcopal church," Mr. Hardy said, "and that's part of the story."
"Education has to be about one generation teaching or explaining values to the next generation," Mr. Hardy said. "Here, it's the celebration of new meeting old."
That meetingoccurs much more obviously at Village Community School, which has built a four-story addition on the corner of 10th and Washington Streets, where its gymnasium -- a converted garage and trucking warehouse -- stood until 2001.
The Washington Street facade of the new building hews to the 60-foot scale of the apartment buildings next door. It intersects a wall on 10th Street that is 14 feet higher, to complement the existing school, which was built in 1885 as Public School 7 and later served as the parochial school of St. Veronica's Roman Catholic Church, on the same block but facing Christopher Street.
As designed by Leo J. Blackman Architects, the 10th Street facade of the new building is built in a matching red brick, with the same pattern of window bays and ornamental two-tone spandrels. Importantly, it also has the same generous 15 1/2-foot floor heights as the old building. Given the overall height of 74 feet, Mr. Blackman said, two more floors could have been squeezed into the structure. "But it wouldn't have had a sense of being part of the existing building," he said.
Eve K. Kleger, the director of Village Community School, said, "Two different divisions would have been contrary to the philosophy of the school."
Founded in 1970 by Sheila Sadler, after the Bank Street School decamped for the Upper West Side, Village Community School has 310 students in kindergarten through eighth grade. The 24,000-square-foot addition is not intended to increase enrollment but to provide desperately needed space.
How desperately? The nurse's office occupies the small wing at stage right in the old assembly hall and the development office occupies the small wing at stage left. The stage itself is used for math, French and music classes. "The development officer can hum all the tunes," Ms. Kleger said.
And until this year, the eighth-grade home rooms were in the basement. Mr. Blackman suggested a motto for the new building: "No child left underground."
Actually, they will be slightly underground in the assembly hall. Roughly half of its 21-foot height is below grade, meaning that the clerestory windows are at sidewalk level. The gymnasium sits atop the building, where there is also a fanciful rooftop play area, covered in three-inch-thick padding made of recycled tires and furnished with plastic Philippe Starck chairs.
The school raised $6.5 million through an Industrial Development Agency bond issue and began a $5 million capital campaign. "We're close to having the total pledge amount," said Steven Skulnik, the immediate past chairman of the school council, equivalent to the board of trustees. The $11.5 million total covers construction costs, fees and the retirement of existing debt.
The structural engineer was Anastos Engineering Associates and the construction manager was C. R. Raimondo & Sons. Mr. Blackman was formerly a partner in Buttrick White & Burtis, which originally won the Village Community School commission but has since dissolved.
ANOTHER Buttrick White & Burtis commission that moved with its partner -- in this case, Samuel G. White, who is now at Platt Byard Dovell White -- was the renovation of 56 East 93rd Street for Spence, a girls' school whose main building is at 22 East 91st Street. It is to be the lower school, kindergarten through fourth grade, serving 241 of Spence's 622 students. The structural engineer is Anastos Engineering and the construction manager is the F. J. Sciame Construction Company.
One of the last mansions built in New York City, 56 East 93rd Street was completed in 1931 for William Goadby Loew, a stockbroker and sportsman. The architect, A. Stewart Walker of Walker & Gillette, worked on the Loew house with his wife, Sybil, a decorator. She undertook a treasure hunt through England for the furnishings, including Georgian pine paneling in the great drawing room, which has monumental Corinthian columns and pilasters.
The house was later occupied by the showman Billy Rose and then by the Smithers Alcoholism Treatment and Training Center of Roosevelt Hospital, from which Spence bought the building in 1999 for $15.5 million.
Spence had searched wide for a site on which to expand, but not far. "We wanted it to be within walking distance because we wanted a campus feeling," said Arlene Joy Gibson, the head of school. The Loew mansion "looked as close as we could envision to being a school," she said, and had the footprint needed for a new gymnasium.
The building's distinctively concave facade appears unchanged and the drawing room, still richly paneled, will serve as the new dining hall. The library will run the length of the 93rd Street facade on the second floor. "It's going to give amazing life back to the street," Mr. White said.
But the structure underwent extensive interior alterations to accommodate 15 new classrooms. "It's almost as if somebody said, 'We like your body, but all the bones are in the wrong place,' " Mr. White said.
The most significant change was the excavation by hoe rams of almost 6,000 cubic yards of Manhattan schist to create a new gym. "It looked," Mr. White said, "like the digging of the Panama Canal." 
To support the building over this newly created void, a steel truss 80 feet long and 12 feet high was constructed at the rear of the ground floor. It is now hidden within the interior of the building, its presence given away only by the unusual thickness of certain walls.
After the weight of the building was transferred from the original structural system to the new one, "the only thing that moved was the front stoop, which dropped about an eighth of an inch," said Robert D. Trostle, senior project manager at Sciame.
What had been a penthouse was expanded into a full fifth floor for second- and fourth-grade classrooms, under a sloping roof set far enough back from the facade that it cannot be seen from street level. The enclosure of a rear balcony permitted the creation of new classroom space on the third, fourth and fifth floors.
Approval by the Landmarks Preservation Commission was not easily won, as neighbors -- Woody Allen among them -- objected in 2000 to plans calling for a new sixth floor with a science laboratory. Elimination of the sixth floor compelled Spence to excavate an additional floor below ground to accommodate the lost program space.
Moving the lower school from 91st Street has permitted a renovation by Fox & Fowle of that 74-year old building. The number of general purpose classrooms will be increased, science labs will be added or rehabilitated, and a drama studio, music lab and common area for the middle school will be built. To finance the renovation of both buildings, Spence has a $50 million capital campaign. "We're very close to making that," Ms. Gibson said. The Industrial Development Agency also issued $16.5 million in bonds.
The new lower school is to open on Sept. 15. Ms. Gibson might have been speaking for any of her counterparts at other schools as she stood outside the building last week and said, above the din of 11th-hour construction, "I want to see it full of children now."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: New $2 Million Center to Open; 
Information On Downtown

 BODY:
An 1,800-square-foot information center is to open on Thursday at 25 Broad Street with a mission of providing anything residents, visitors and businesses want to know about Lower Manhattan: office and store vacancies, updates on the project at the World Trade Center site, the closest Chinese restaurant to City Hall.
 "Hopefully, there will never be a question we can't answer," said Julie Menin, founder and president of Wall Street Rising, which created the center and will run it. 
The organization is a nonprofit coalition of businesses, cultural institutions, residents and others, and was set up two weeks after the attacks of Sept. 11 to encourage economic development and community spirit on Chambers Street and below. It now has 30,000 members and has raised $6.5 million for its projects. 
 The new $2 million information center was designed pro bono by the Rockwell Group and Fred Schwartz Architects.
It is to have a 12-by-9-foot three-dimensional Plexiglas model of Lower Manhattan and plasma screens listing local events. Besides a half-dozen computers at the center, a Web site (www.downtowninfocenter.org) is to be running on Thursday with a global information system providing coordinates of every building downtown. All residential buildings and their contacts are to be listed on the Web site.
The center is to have seating for up to 54 for lectures, book signings, storytelling and scavenger hunts for children. Its hours are to be 8:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. on weekdays and 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. on weekends.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; 
Daisy Eagan, Patrick Comer

 BODY:
Daisy Ann Eagan, a daughter of Richard Eagan of Brooklyn and the late Andrea Boroff Eagan, was married yesterday to Patrick Brittan Comer, a son of Judith W. Comer and the Rev. J. Fletcher Comer of Greensboro, Ala. The bridegroom's father, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in Middleburgh, N.Y., at the weekend house of the bride's father and stepmother, Elizabeth Ostrow.
 The bride, 23, will continue to use her name professionally. She is a stage and film actor, and won a Tony award in 1991 for her role as Mary Lennox in the musical production of "The Secret Garden." In 1999 and 2000, she performed several roles in James Joyce's "The Dead" at the Belasco Theater. Her film credits include "Losing Isaiah," which was released in 1995, and "Tony and Tina's Wedding," scheduled to be released in 2004. Her father is a visual and performing artist who performed his one-man show, "Alive on the Inside," at Sideshows by the Seashore in Coney Island in July. Her mother wrote about medical issues and was the author of "Why Am I So Miserable If These Are the Best Years of My Life?" (Lippincott, Williams & Wilkins, 1976) and "The Newborn Mother: Stages of Her Growth" (Little Brown, 1985). She was also the founding president of the National Writers Union. The bride's stepmother is the director of artistic planning for the Orchestra of St. Luke's and is an independent record producer. 
The bridegroom, 29, is a financial and market research consultant in Los Angeles. He graduated from the University of the South in Sewanee, Tenn., and received an M.B.A. from Columbia earlier this month. His mother is the resource teacher for gifted and talented students at the Prattville Intermediate School in Prattville, Ala. His father is the rector of both St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Greensboro and St. Wilfrid's Episcopal Church in Marion, Ala., as well as the chaplain at Marion Military Institute, a high school and junior college in Marion, where he teaches moral philosophy, psychology and economics.

HEADLINE: THE AGE OF DISSONANCE; 
Summer of Sun? We Wuz Robbed

BYLINE:  By BOB MORRIS

 BODY:
THE weather was lovely last Tuesday in Brunswick, Me. But that doesn't mean Barbara Held was happy. She was sitting in her office at Bowdoin College there watching the students roll in with their parents for orientation and feeling so miserable that she was giving herself a headache. 
 "Summer's over and we didn't even have one," said Dr. Held, a psychology professor. "This is the only time I have all year to get my writing done." 
 She was aware, of course, that she wasn't the only unhappy resident in Maine. Penobscot Bay had been a vichyssoise of fog for much of the summer, provoking, she said, even the most reserved Mainers to complain at surprising length.
"My husband is a sailor, and he hated the fog," she said. Well, he wasn't alone this year. 
All the Northeastern resorts had a total washout of a June (pun intended), while New York's 10.27 inches of rain made it the wettest June in a century. July had 14 days of rain, and August had its share of gray days, along with one black one. 
When rainwater soaked the basements of homeowners on lovely Georgica Pond in East Hampton, someone illegally dug a ditch that drained it in early July, leaving a quasi mud flat all summer. There were wildfires in Montana. And Europe had beastly killer heat.
During the mid-August blackout in New York, raw sewage closed beaches around the city, spoiling another weekend. And if that isn't enough, the calendar is shortchanging us with a Labor Day on Sept. 1, the shortest possible summer.
Shall we call this one "The Endless Bummer?" 
"Or maybe the summer of our discontent," said Steven Stolman, a designer with shops in Southampton, Palm Beach and New York, who had to struggle harder than usual to make up for his dismal sales in June. "But then expectations are always too high in summer when you have to fit all that fun into three months. Maybe that's why I prefer Palm Beach to Southampton. The season is so much longer." 
Yes, but so is the chance of getting hit by a hurricane. 
And as far as Kitty Hawks is concerned, she was, but in Westchester. The garden at her weekend home has become a soaked, sick bay with black spots and mildew on her roses and dampened bulbs rotting in the saturated earth.
"I love my garden more than life itself," said Ms. Hawks, an interior designer, "and this summer my garden has been drowning."
Maybe she would have preferred baking in Italy? That's what happened to Silvano Marchetto, the ever-cool owner of Da Silvano, the downtown power restaurant, who arrived in Tuscany only to find his lovely native Florence strangely deserted. 
"I thought it was the economy, but then I realized it was the heat," he said. "The temperature in my car was over 100 degrees." After fainting at lunch, Mr. Marchetto began his sojourn under the Tuscan sun in the hospital. "Even the beach was unbearable," he said of Forte dei Marmi, the chic resort where Martha Stewart and Sirio Maccioni, the owner of Le Cirque 2000, were also stewing in their own juices. "You had to run over the hot sand to the water if you didn't want your feet to get burned."
At least the fashionable were sweating off their pounds over there. Around New York, they had lost the usual incentive to shed weight for summer, said Robert Levine, a Manhattan diet doctor.
"The weather in June wasn't good enough for people to think about getting into the kind of clothes that make them want to lose weight," he said.
Nor were they inspired to rent houses in the Hamptons in the numbers they usually do. "It wasn't the summer people had hoped it would be," said Helen Rattray, editor of The East Hampton Star.
But then, is it ever? What season can possibly hold up under such pressure of expectations? Since we were children, we have had it ingrained in our psyches that summer is our reward for working hard all year. You spend large amounts of time and money on a second home or a rental house, and what do you get for it?
"We ended up having to clean the mold off the floors and walls in August from the cold, wet June," said Erica Silverman, an Upper East Sider who rents on Martha's Vineyard. "But I'm so disappointed by other things in life that I can't be that disappointed by thesummer. I think it's a great luxury to be able to be disappointed by the weather." 
Is it possible that the more you have, the more you have to complain about? 
Perhaps that's why high-end vacationers look so dour under their pastels and tans. It's almost as if the stress of having to have all that fun is too much for them. And what about all the children of privilege returning from camps after a summer of torturing parents with letters of woe?
"A counselor told us exactly how many sheets of toilet paper we were allowed to use!" one 9-year-old from Manhattan shrieked about her camp in New Hampshire. Others carped about flies, bad food and turtles in the lake.
Well, God invented language, say Jane Wagner and Lily Tomlin, because of our deep need to complain, and Samuel Johnson once observed that "if a man talks of his misfortunes there is something in them that is not disagreeable to him." Maybe complaining is just a way of showing off, like the bullfrogs carrying on at this time of year. 
Of course, when Labor Day comes so early and people don't feel as ready as usual to embrace the fall, a little carping does seem warranted.
"Look, the awful truth is that on the first day of summer the days are already getting shorter," said Dr. Held, the put-upon psychology professor at Bowdoin, whose book "Stop Smiling, Start Kvetching" (Griffin, 2001) suggests that having to smile through life's problems adds insult to injury. "But I do have to wonder, if the summer was so bad this year, why are we so upset that it's over?"
Let's save that question for the day after tomorrow.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
A Way To Break The Cycle Of Servitude

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
ON this Labor Day weekend, let us remember low-wage workers. Twenty percent of the work force -- 26 million people -- earn $8.23 an hour or less. Most of them are not teenagers snagging pocket money, but adults supporting families. With so little income, too many Americans are pushed into poverty, and getting out of this trap is increasingly difficult.
 As many studies have shown, rising income inequality has driven people apart. And low-wage workers, occupying the bottom rung in this ruptured society, have descended into what amounts to a servant class. It is not their work that makes them servants. We need factory assemblers, store clerks, child care workers and the telephone operators who field calls to "800" numbers, processing much of the nation's commerce. 
 What makes them servants is the miserable pay. Measuring status by wage, as many Americans do, no one -- the employers of low-wage worker, the public or the low-wage workers themselves -- seems to value this class of work. Promotion, or higher pay, would be a way out. Unfortunately, neither solution kicks in very often. More than in the past, low-wage workers are stuck in place.
"There is not any kind of sinister approach by companies or individuals to make this happen," said Jeffrey Joerres, chief executive of Manpower Inc., the temporary-help agency, which places many low-wage workers. "But it is the path that we are on."
That path has become self-perpetuating. Employers are under constant pressure to cut costs. Hospitals, for example, have to bid for good medical staffs, so they offset this cost by squeezing the wages of unskilled kitchen workers. Or they outsource food preparation to contractors who pay even less. In either case, the result is a constant, dispiriting turnover. But it is tolerated. The low wage more than offsets the cost of one or two days of training for each new hire.
So wages barely rise. Adjusted for inflation, the $8.23 an hour today is only 9 percent higher than the $7.55 that the workers in the 20th percentile earned 30 years ago, according to the Economic Policy Institute. All of that improvement came in the very tight labor markets of the late 1990's, when even low-wage workers could command higher pay.
The constant turnover of people in these jobs often leaves the impression that low-wage workers are irresponsible and unambitious. But Eileen Appelbaum, director of the Center for Women and Work at Rutgers University, offers a different explanation. "If you work in a hospital as a nurse's aide, you care about patients, and you are asked to care for more people than you can safely care for and you are afraid you will hurt someone," she said. "So, you leave."
Or you have a personal crisis -- a sick child, for example. Low-wage jobs seldom come with time off, "so you quit, knowing that when you can work again, there will be another rotten job you can get," she added.
Training is a way up the wage ladder, but employers of low-wage workers seldom offer it or give those workers time away from daily tasks. Manpower Inc. offers training, but for jobs that pay $9 an hour and up. Most of the more than 180,000 people that Manpower sends out each day earn at least this wage, but 30 percent draw only $8.50 an hour or less. For them, the instruction is less than respectful. Job readiness, it is called.
"We have a whole set of videotapes that are uncomfortable for me to watch," Mr. Joerres said. "You need to arrive on time. You can only take breaks at break time. Have you taken a shower?"
FAR from lifting these workers, the unfettered American marketplace holds them down. They need help, ideally from employers, if only those employers could find their way back to the pre-1970's system of long-term employment in low-skilled jobs that included training, promotions and raises. In some places, unions still force this to happen -- at New York City hospitals, for example -- and no hospital is at a disadvantage because each is bound by the same wage scale. But in this era of disappearing unions, that is not likely to work. 
Raising the minimum wage would be a quicker route, if only Congress and the administration would make that a priority. The minimum wage once went up regularly, peaking in 1968 at the equivalent of $7.08 an hour today, adjusted for inflation. That's nearly $2 above today's actual minimum of $5.15 an hour. Just restoring the minimum to its old value of $7.08 would also push up wages that are just above the minimum. 
Suddenly, the bottom 20 percent of the work force would be making up to $10 an hour, instead of $8.23. That might be a large enough raise to justify training and job security, and new respect for the men and women in these jobs -- respect as workers, not servants.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Yachts to Call Your Own (If Only for a Vacation)

BYLINE:  By JANE L. LEVERE

 BODY:
CHRISTINE JORDAN and William Krohn celebrated their 10th wedding anniversary last winter in style: they took a weeklong cruise through the British Virgin Islands on a 46-foot yacht they had chartered, complete with a captain and a chef. The couple, from Cleveland, dined every evening on the deck and set their own agenda for the trip. "We could sail or walk on the beach or around town however long we wanted, receive personalized snorkeling instructions," said Dr. Jordan, 53, an anesthesiologist. "That was lovely."
 One of the best parts of the trip, said Dr. Jordan and Mr. Krohn, 51, a newspaper editor, was the price. The charter, arranged by Ed Hamilton & Company in Whitefield, Me., cost $4,600, or around $330 a day per person. (Air fare and the traditional 15 percent tip for the crew were extra.) 
 Yacht charters are clearly no longer only for the rich and famous. The price that Dr. Jordan and Mr. Krohn paid for theirs was similar to the average for commercial cruises on many luxury ships. But other charter deals can cost far less, travel experts say, during off-peak seasons for your destination, or if you book well in advance and have flexible plans. If you are willing to hoist the sail, mop the deck and stay the course -- in other words, to do everything yourself -- the price may fall further.
Travel experts say charters have gained popularity as people seek creative ways to customize their vacations. Charters are available in waters around the world, from the Caribbean, which is most popular in the winter, to the Mediterranean, South Pacific, Pacific Northwest and Alaska, most popular in the summer. Although charter brokers and companies can usually find a yacht for you anywhere, some specialize in specific regions. Interpac, for example, specializes in Mexico, the Pacific Northwest and Turkey, and CEO Expeditions specializes in Alaska.
Rates vary widely. For $1,053 a week, experienced sailors can take a so-called bareboat charter -- the kind on which you do everything yourself -- on a 32-foot Moorings sailboat large enough for four passengers in the British Virgin Islands, through Oct. 24. The price does not include food and air fare. For those looking to be pampered, about $100,000 buys a week from Yachtstore on a 130-foot luxury powerboat, large enough for 10 passengers, in the Caribbean in the winter, with a crew of seven. The price does not include air fare.
Sarah Woods, a senior vice president for account management in Santa Ana, Calif., for Navigant International, a travel management company, has sailed on both cruise ships and chartered yachts with crews. A charter vacation is ideal, she said, for "an adventuresome person who doesn't like a formal or regimented vacation."
"You've got to like the water and sun, and to want to entertain yourself," she said. "It's much more flexible than a cruise vacation."
She prefers yachts with crews to bareboat charters. "When I'm on vacation, I don't want to make up a bed or cook, and my husband's not experienced as a sailor," she said.
In planning a yacht charter vacation to any destination, consider your budget and whether you prefer a powerboat or sailboat or a sedentary or active vacation. "A broker will interview you and ask you these questions, and you should know all these things before you make your call," said Kenny Wooton, editor in chief of Yachting magazine.
Although most brokers have access to the same yachts, some are more knowledgeable than others. You can find an experienced company through personal references, travel agencies that arrange charters or the industry's main trade associations, which include the American Yacht Charter Association, www.ayca.net; the Charter Yacht Brokers Association, www.cyba.net; and the Mediterranean Yacht Brokers Association, www.mybamembers.com.
Most brokers require payment of half the total cost upon booking, with the balance due immediately before departure. They will usually deposit these funds into an escrow account. Because deposits are generally nonrefundable, most brokers recommend that you buy trip cancellation insurance, which can help you recoup any losses if you or a relative fall ill and you cannot make the trip, or if your trip is disrupted by a tropical storm.
If you want to charter a specific boat during peak weeks -- like Christmas or Presidents' Day week in the Caribbean, or July and August in the Mediterranean -- brokers recommend booking 6 to 12 months in advance. These days, though, many travelers prefer to plan closer to the time of departure because of economic and political uncertainties, travel experts say. 
If you book late, of course, the selection of yachts may be limited. But waiting can also lead to discounts.
Some bargains, for example, are available now for Caribbean charters this fall and winter: through Oct. 24, the Moorings is cutting the price of a two-week, 41-foot bareboat charter for six passengers in the British Virgin Islands by 25 percent, to $3,308. For winter bookings made by Oct. 1, Ed Hamilton has a weeklong all-inclusive charter for two, with a crew, on a 44-foot catamaran in the Virgin Islands for $7,980; after Oct. 1, the rate rises to $9,000.
Another way to save money is to charter an older yacht. Rates at the Moorings, for example, are lower for its three- to five-year-old yachts than for its one- and two-year-old ones.
Whatever you pay, chartering lets you spend quality time with friends or family, said Ms. Woods, the executive from Navigant.
"And, unlike on a big ship, you never have to dress up; there are no formal nights," she said. "I was in shorts or a swimsuit all the time."

Charter companies and yacht brokerage firms can match travelers with yachts that suit their budgets and interests. Charter companies include these:

The Moorings, www.moorings.com.
Sunsail, www.sunsail.com.
CEO Expeditions, www.ceoexpeditions.com.

Brokers include these:

Camper & Nicholsons International, www.cnconnect.com.
Fraser Yachts Worldwide, www.fraseryachts.com.
Ed Hamilton & Company, www.ed-hamilton.com.
Jubilee Yacht Charters, www.jubileeyachtcharters.com.
Liveras Yachts, www.liverasyachts.com.
Yachtstore, www.yachtstore.com.
Interpac Yachts, www.interpacyachts.com.

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD; 
A German Town Tells Volkswagen: We Are Family

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: WOLFSBURG, Germany 

 BODY:
THEY don't call it Motown or Motor City, but this industrial burg in the heaths of Lower Saxony now has a nickname that evokes its status as Germany's answer to Detroit.
 For the next six weeks, Wolfsburg, the birthplace and home of Volkswagen, will be known as Golfsburg. 
 The mayor of Wolfsburg, Rolf Schnellecke, ordered the name to be changed on road signs, official letterheads, municipal Web sites and some public buildings to help promote Volkswagen's introduction of its new Golf, the fifth generation of the best-selling hatchback. "We wanted to do it as a sign of sympathy and friendship for Volkswagen," Mr. Schnellecke said. "The Golf is the economic base of the company. If it is a success, the whole city and region will prosper." 
The mayor's campaign, which will run through the period of the Golf's rollout, has drawn complaints from critics who say the name change is hokey and, worse, an unseemly bid by a German city to further the business goals of its largest employer.
The critics, Mr. Schnellecke shoots back, are missing the point. "They don't understand the special relationship between VW and Wolfsburg," he said. "This is not like any other German city."
Indeed, Wolfsburg is the quintessential company town -- a city of 125,000 that was founded in 1938 by order of Hitler to turn out Europe's first mass-produced vehicle, the Volkswagen, or People's Car.
To say Wolfsburg depends on Volkswagen the way Detroit depends on General Motors doesn't begin to capture the symbiosis. Six decades after its founding, Wolfsburg remains a support system for a gargantuan car factory.
These days, that factory is ramping up for Volkswagen's most important product introduction in a decade. Since replacing the ubiquitous Beetle in 1974, the Golf has been Volkswagen's best-selling model. Until last year, when it was overtaken by the Peugeot 206, it was the top-selling car in Europe.
Volkswagen hopes the new Golf will reclaim that title. Each time the company redesigns the car -- it has done so five times in 29 years -- Europe's automobile industry holds its breath.
"This is huge," said Thomas Aney, an analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein in Frankfurt. "Even Volkswagen says it is basically a two-model company -- the Golf and the Passat -- with the emphasis on the Golf."
Expectations are running high. About 400 reporters descended on Wolfsburg last Monday to watch Volkswagen's chief executive, Bernd Pischetsrieder, roll out the car. More will swarm over it at the Frankfurt auto show next month.
At first glance, the new Golf looks a lot like the old Golf. Volkswagen has added a few gadgets like electronically adjustable seats. And the car is slightly longer and wider than its predecessor -- a reflection, one Volkswagen official joked, of the expanding girth of its customers.
The company hopes to sell 135,000 new Golfs in 2003 and 600,000 next year. It has not announced when the car will go on sale in the United States, where it trails the Jetta sedan in sales. "They have a lot of momentum behind the launch," Mr. Aney said.
Volkswagen has said little about the Golfsburg campaign, aware that it risks being perceived as meddling in municipal affairs. Mayor Schnellecke said the idea grew out of a meeting he held with journalists.
The Golf is important to Wolfsburg not only because it accounts for 15 percent of Volkswagen's total unit sales, but also because it is actually produced here, in the sprawling factory that dates from the 1940's.
The company has turned over a cavernous production hall to the Golf, outfitting it with the latest in robotic machines. It assembles other models, including a minivan, in Wolfsburg, but the Golf is its bread and butter.
Though much of Volkswagen's assembly line is mechanized, the factory still employs 25,000 workers.
WOLFSBURG has known both feast and famine as Volkswagen has weathered the vicissitudes of the automobile market. Its population spiked in the 1950's and 60's, as Volkswagen grew into a global company, importing foreign workers to meet its demand for labor.
In the early 1990's, however, Volkswagen hit a rough patch, with collapsing sales in the United States and doubts about the quality of its cars. Wolfsburg lost 20,000 jobs in three years, as the company was forced to cut production. The local unemployment rate jumped to nearly 20 percent.
That period brought a painful reckoning. While Volkswagen fought to rebuild its reputation under the forceful leadership of Ferdinand Piech, then its chief executive, Wolfsburg set about diversifying its commercial base beyond Volkswagen.
"It was the starting point for a restructuring of the city," said Klaus-Jorg Siegfried, the director of a museum of city history. "The city and the factory showed that they were able to work together."
With help from the company, Wolfsburg began attracting automotive suppliers and service companies. Mayor Schnellecke himself owns a component supplier, started by his father. Volkswagen is a big customer, attesting to the web of ties between town and firm.
The partnership between Volkswagen and Wolfsburg has flowered further in the last five years -- nowhere more than in Autostadt, a 62-acre complex next to the factory that looks like a cross between a theme park and a world's fair. It encompasses a museum, a Ritz-Carlton hotel and a soaring visitors' center, where customers can pick up their new cars. "We don't sell products here; we sell values," said Nicholas Batten, a spokesman for the Autostadt.
Playing to the German obsession with cars, the park has become one of the country's biggest tourist attractions, drawing two million visitors a year. China's former president, Jiang Zemin, has stayed at the Ritz-Carlton; so have Mick Jagger and the other members of the Rolling Stones.
THE park is the centerpiece of Wolfsburg's improbable effort to transform itself from an industrial site into a tourist destination. With the 1990 reunification of Germany, residents note that Wolfsburg is centrally located.
It is a far cry from the immediate postwar period, when this was a grim industrial outpost, heavily bombed by the Allies and lying less than 10 miles from the barbed-wire border of East Germany. "We were living on the edge of the Western world," said Mayor Schnellecke, as he rode past the twinkling glass towers of the Autostadt in a Phaeton, Volkswagen's majestic new sedan.
The view from the mayor's creamy leather seats looks bright, but fortunes can turn quickly in the car business. Even as Volkswagen trumpets the new Golf, it is struggling with declining profits and fresh questions about its quality, following glitches in some models in the United States.
Nor is the future of the Golf boundless. Volkswagen built nearly 900,000 Golfs in 1999, the first full year of the last redesign. Its 2004 sales target of 600,000 reflects both the fiercer competition from rivals like Peugeot and the splintering of the market.
"The number is not overoptimistic, and it is not pessimistic," said a Volkswagen spokesman, Gunther Scherelis. "It is realistic."
For the people of Golfsburg, the precise numbers are less important than the Golf's dependability. As one of the Mr. Scherelis's colleagues, Manfred Grieger, put it: "The Beetle was the car of the century. The Golf will be the next one, perhaps."

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
4 Ways to Build an Index (None of Them Ideal)

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a service of CBS MarketWatch. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
INVESTORS have long been accustomed to the variety of benchmarks for the stock market, and to relatively minor differences in their returns.
 But the differences in recent years have been "some of the most extreme ever seen," according to Jay R. Ritter, a finance professor at the University of Florida in Gainesville. Some broad market indexes are near their record highs, for example, and are well above their level of March 2000, when the Internet bubble burst. But other, equally broad indexes are more than 30 percent below that level. 
 Why such a mess? Isn't there a single fact of the matter for market performance?
Unfortunately, no. The most obvious definition of the stock market is the total dollar value of all publicly traded stocks. This is what is measured by the Wilshire 5000, which, despite its name, currently reflects the performances of the more than 7,000 regularly traded stocks in the United States. On July 31, that index was down more than 30 percent from its high in March 2000.
This way of compiling a benchmark, known as value weighting, may be the most widely used. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, for example, is figured this way.
But the method has a drawback. A stock's weight in the index is a function of its market capitalization. Because the market cap of Microsoft, for example, is 35 times more than Apple Computer's, the weight of Microsoft in such an index is also 35 times greater. Because many money managers are just as likely to pick a small- or mid-cap stock as a large one, the appropriate benchmark for judging their stock-picking abilities is one that gives equal weight to each stock. 
The solution to the problem seems straightforward: calculate the average percentage change of all stocks, without regard to market cap. Indexes that do this are known as arithmetic averages.
Wilshire Associates says the Wilshire 5000 would have been 24 percent higher on July 31 this year than it was on March 31, 2000, had it been an arithmetic average. That is 54 percentage points greater than its value-weighted return.
Arithmetic averages have a drawback, too: their returns will always be higher than what an investor would earn by buying and holding the average stock. This difference is caused by the way arithmetic averages deal with underperforming and overperforming stocks in order to preserve stocks' equal weight. 
AS a solution to that bias, some people have suggested a third way. Instead of averaging stocks' percentage changes, it would base the indexes on an average of those changes' logarithms, which results in lower returns than those of arithmetic averages. The Value Line Geometric Composite uses this procedure to calculate the average return of 1,700 widely followed stocks. As of July 31, it was 27 percent below its level on March 31, 2000, while the Value Line Arithmetic Composite, an arithmetic average of those same stocks, was 20 percent higher.
But averaging the logarithm of stocks' percentage gains causes an excessive correction of the upward bias of arithmetic averages. Andrew Metrick, a finance professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, said that returns calculated this way would always be lower than those of a portfolio divided equally among all stocks, except in the very unlikely event that all stocks had the same returns.
A fourth method, used by the Dow Jones industrial average, has even more serious drawbacks. A stock's weight in the Dow depends on its price, which makes the Dow an appropriate benchmark only if you are likelier to buy expensive stocks.
In the absence of a perfect benchmark, the best course for you and your money manager is to agree in advance on the benchmark against which he will be judged. Never allow a manager to pick that benchmark after the fact, because he will undoubtedly find one that makes his performance look remarkable.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
In These 401(k)'s, Workers Do Less to Save More

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH HARRIS

 BODY:
PEOPLE who never think about investing for retirement may soon find that their bosses are stepping in -- by forcing them to make decisions about the future. 
 Alarmed by the disinclination of employees to save, more companies are aiming to increase participation in their 401(k) retirement plans and to set them up so employees commit to making steadily larger contributions. 
 In July, for example, Safelite Glass of Columbus, Ohio, an automobile glass company and manager of property and casualty claims, started arranging for employees to automatically contribute more each year to their 401(k)'s.
"In some respects, we were trying to protect people from themselves," said Doug Herron, the chief financial officer, who serves on the company's retirement committee and helped oversee changes in the plan. 
New research from the field of behavioral finance, which draws on psychology and economics, provides data on the disconnect between the desire to prepare for retirement and the failure to do so. Researchers have found that for many investors, the task of sifting through pamphlets about their company's 401(k) plans ranges from unpleasant to horrible. 
Some people end up doing nothing when confronted with the need to pick savings goals, select appropriate asset allocations, screen investment choices and rebalance their portfolios regularly.
"We know if you ask people, they say they would like to save more," said Richard H. Thaler, the Robert P. Gwinn professor of economics and behavioral science at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business. Economists make fun of statements like that, Dr. Thaler said, because it is obvious that people are not acting on their expressed desires, suggesting that they are insincere. 
"But what's true is, we don't make statements about everything," he said. "We don't say, 'Gee, I'd really like to smoke, or eat more French fries.' When people say that, then you have an opportunity. They're telling you that they would like to do something. They have good intentions."
Dr. Thaler and Shlomo Benartzi, an associate professor of accounting at the Anderson School at the University of California at Los Angeles, have come up with a way to turn good intentions into results. They have developed a framework called Save More Tomorrow, which allows investors to save more by committing to gradual increases over time. 
"We know that people are not saving enough, and the recent market didn't help," Dr. Benartzi said. "The 401(k) accounts turned into 201(k)'s."
Research shows that when employees have to fill out paperwork, their participation in savings plans is low. When they must open their own 401(k) plans, the participation rate for workers with less than 12 months of tenure is 50 percent, compared with 90 percent when employees are enrolled automatically but may opt out, said Brigitte Madrian, an associate professor in the business and public policy department at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. 
"What's missing from the 401(k) arena at most companies is something that makes it easy for the people who are not Wall Street financiers to participate in the 401(k) plan -- something that gets people in early, with a sensible contribution rate and sensible asset allocation," Dr. Madrian said. "I'm encouraged over the last couple of years we can see companies starting to recognize this." 
Research also shows that giving employees too many choices can confuse them. Sheena S. Iyengar, the Sanford C. Bernstein associate professor of leadership and ethics at the Columbia Business School, has found that 401(k) participation peaks at 75 percent when a retirement plan offers two investment options. Her results, based on data from 647 company retirement plans run by the Vanguard Group, also show that participation drops to 60 percent when investors have 60 choices. With each additional 10 choices, participation falls by 2 percent.
"I don't think people are choosing not to choose," Dr. Iyengar said. "They're thinking: 'I don't have the time right now to go through this. I'll do my homework later.' They're not consciously thinking, 'Let me be irrational.' "
After a periodic review of its retirement plan offerings, the Ford Motor Company, which once had 60 fund choices, reduced the number to 36 last year by dropping some and adding others. 
"The goal was to offer an entire portfolio without being redundant and without making the entire portfolio so large that it could be confusing for employees," said Anne Marie Gattari, a company spokeswoman. 
Some employers are making or considering changes in their plans. This fall, TIAA-CREF, the financial services company, will adjust the retirement plan it offers at Loyola University of Chicago. Employees will be encouraged to increase the funding of their plan each July, when they get their annual raises. That way, the deduction will cancel out the increase -- resulting in a less painful way to save. 
Also in the fall, T. Rowe Price will begin its version of automatic contribution increases. Ten of the plans it administers for companies will allow investors to increase contributions automatically each year. 
Vanguard rolled out one of the first such savings systems, for Philips Electronics North America, and will offer it to other companies this fall, said Stephen P. Utkus, a retirement researcher at Vanguard. 
"We have to come up with a more flexible model that gets them to a good place without them having to make a lot of active choices," Mr. Utkus said.
Philips started its program in April 2002 for two divisions. In both, the initial average savings rate was around 3 percent. Each division was offered the same program, but employees in one of them were given the option of meeting with a financial planner. 
Dr. Benartzi and Dr. Thaler studied their investment decisions. In the division that did not have access to the planner, 17 percent of employees chose to raise their savings each year. But in the division that had access to the planner, 38 percent chose to increase their savings. Nearly 42 percent of employees in that division met with the planner, and four-fifths of those who did increased their savings. 
SAFELITE already has a track record in tweaking its retirement plan to improve savings. In 1998, the company began enrolling employees automatically in its 401(k). Since then, participation has doubled, to about 95 percent of the more than 6,000 employees.
But the company also wanted its workers to continue to save more. Under the new plan, which is based on the ideas of Dr. Thaler and Dr. Benartzi, the employee contribution automatically increases by one percentage point a year until the federal limit of $12,000 a year is reached. Again, employees can opt out of that schedule of increases.
Robert P. Brooks, 39, who has supervised sales staff for Safelite since 2000, said that before joining the company, he had never given much thought to investing. "Prior to coming on board, I really neglected that part of my life," he said.
But starting in July, when the company changed its plan, he agreed to increase his 401(k) contribution each July by one percentage point.
"It truly is the easiest and most comfortable way to do more in my case for my retirement," Mr. Brooks said. "I don't have the time to invest in researching the market and mutual funds and stocks. I would almost have to go back to school to understand; it's an overwhelming prospect for an average person."
But now, Mr. Brooks finds himself passing along what he has learned to his four daughters.
"I certainly want to help them prepare for life," he said.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST SIDE; 
On a Pier Made for Working, the Public Wants a Place to Play

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE

 BODY:
Some piers are made for fishing, others for strolling. Pier 94, which runs from 52nd Street to 54th Street along the Hudson River, is reserved strictly forworking. 
 For five years, Pier 94 has been used as an exhibition hall known as the UnConvention Center. While other riverfront piers have been refashioned into public parks, Pier 94 sticks out like a private fortress, cordoned off from the public by chain-link fence and barbed wire. 
 Park advocates had hoped to reclaim parts of the pier. But the city, which owns the pier, is now proposing to extend the UnConvention Center's lease for up to 12 years, and shrink the amount of public space required under the city's waterfront zoning rules. 
"The proposal restricts public access on public property," said John Doswell, a member of Community Board 4, which includes Clinton.
 Of particular concern, Mr. Doswell added, is how the convention center will relate to the future Clinton Cove Park, a three-acre space that abuts the north side of the pier. 
The UnConvention Center was established under the Giuliani administration, in part to replace the space lost for midsize tradeshows when the Coliseum at Columbus Circle was demolished. Such shows typically draw 2,000 to 3,000 visitors a day. 
 The T-shaped structure, which was built in 1959 as a Cunard Line freight terminal, has 190,000 square feet of exhibition space on a single floor. The finger building, the stem of the T, juts out about 750 feet over the river and is ringed by a catwalk. The head house, the top of the T, faces the West Side Highway and serves as the entrance.
 Community groups wanted the entire catwalk to be open to the public. In addition, they wanted to enlarge the public space by lopping off a third of the head house, transforming the T into an L. But the development group, led by Elyse N. Kroll, a trade show producer and president of the UnConvention Center, said that was not economically or logistically feasible. 
 Instead, the developers have offered to keep two sides of the catwalk open; the south side would be used to store heating and cooling equipment. Last week, the developers also offered to carve out a small, 650-square-foot cafe at the north edge of the head house, with restrooms.
 Neighbors said that the public was still being shortchanged, but they might support the cafeanyway. "I don't think we can get much more out of them," said Pam Frederick, a Community Board 4 member. DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: CITY LORE; 
Brother, Can You Spare a Day?

BYLINE:  By EDWARD T. O'DONNELL; Edward T. O'Donnell is the author of "Ship Ablaze: The Tragedy of the Steamboat General Slocum," published this year by Broadway Books.

 BODY:
ONE hundred-twenty-one years ago Labor Day meant something more than a three-day weekend and the unofficial end of summer. On Sept. 5, 1882, thousands of workers in New York risked being fired for taking an unauthorized day off to participate in festivities honoring honest toil and the rights of labor. This first commemoration of Labor Day testified to labor's rising power and unity in the Gilded Age and its sense that both were necessary to withstand the growing power of capital. 
 The Labor Day holiday originated with the Central Labor Union, a local labor federation formed the previous January to promote the interests of workers in the New York area. The organization immediately became a formidable force, staging protest rallies, lobbying state legislators and organizing strikes and boycotts. By August membership boomed to 56 unions representing 80,000 workers. 
 But the organization's activists wanted to do more than just increase membership and win strikes. They wanted to build worker solidarity in the face of jarring changes wrought by the Industrial Revolution. 
 Gilded Age workers were alarmed by the growing power of employers over their employees. Bosses were free to increase hours, slash wages and fire workers at will. Equally disconcerting was the growing gap between rich and poor, a disparity made shockingly clear in the Gilded Age by the growing army of poorly paid workers and the emergence of millionaire industrialists and financiers with names like Morgan, Rockefeller and Carnegie. 
 Nowhere were those changes more apparent than in New York, the capital of capitalism, a city populated with abundant laborers, ambitious entrepreneurs willing to exploit them in their relentless pursuit of profit, and political leaders unwilling to exercise restraint. These developments, labor leaders noted, called into question the future of the American Republic. 
 The organization's activists believed that the establishment of a day celebrating the honest worker would open their eyes and compel them to reclaim their dwindling rights. Doing so in New York, the city where the excesses of industrial capitalism were most evident and media exposure was greatest, would send a message to workers nationwide. 
 The precise identity of the Central Labor Union leader who in May 1882 first proposed the idea of establishing Labor Day remains a mystery. Some accounts say it was P.J. McGuire, general secretary of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners and the future co-founder of the A.F.L., who proposed the idea. Others argue that it was another man with a similar last name, machinist Matthew Maguire. Whatever the answer, both men played crucial roles in promoting and organizing the original holiday. 
After months of preparation, the chosen day -- Sept. 5, a Tuesday -- finally arrived. Optimism among the organizers ran high, but no one knew how many workers would turn out. Few could expect their employers to grant them a day off and many feared getting fired for union activity. When William G. McCabe, the parade's first grand marshal and a popular member of Local No. 6 of the International Typographers Union, arrived an hour before the parade's start, only a few dozen workers stood milling about City Hall Park.
 To the relief of Mr. McCabe and other organizers, some 400 men and a brass band assembled by the time the parade stepped off at 10 a.m. Initially, the small group of marchers faced ridicule from bystanders and interruptions in the line of march because policemen refused to stop traffic at intersections. As the parade continued north up Broadway, however, it swelled in size as union after union fell into line from side streets. Jeers turned into cheers as the spectacle of labor solidarity grew more impressive. 
 Marchers held aloft signs that spoke to their pride as workers and to the fear that they were losing political power and economic standing: "To the Workers Should Belong All Wealth," "Strike With the Ballot," "Don't Smoke Cigars Without the Union Label" and "Eight Hours for a Legal Day's Work."
 Many wore their traditional work uniforms and aprons and walked behind wagons displaying their handwork. Others dressed in their holiday best.
 After moving up Fifth Avenue, past the mansions of tycoons like Vanderbilt and Morgan, the grand procession of 5,000 or more terminated at 42nd Street and Sixth Avenue. There participants boarded elevated trains that took them to Wendel's Elm Park at West 92nd Street for a huge picnic. By late afternoon upward of 25,000 people jammed the park to participate in the festivities and consume copious amounts of food and beer. Members of craft unions gathered under banners put up throughout the park. Several bands played while speaker after speaker held forth from stages and soapboxes. 
 Thrilled with the success of their first effort, Central Labor Union leaders staged a second Labor Day the following year and drew even more participants. In 1884 the organization officially designated the first Monday in September as the annual Labor Day, calling upon workers to "Leave your benches, leave your shops, join in the parade and attend the picnic." Upwards of 20,000 marched that year, including a contingent of African-American workers. The first women marched in 1885. 
 WITH such an impressive start, the tradition of an annual Labor Day holiday quickly gained popularity across the country. By 1886 Labor Day had become a national event. Some 20,000 workers marched in Manhattan, and 10,000 more in Brooklyn, while 25,000 turned out in Chicago and 15,000 in Boston. Politicians took notice, and in 1887 five states, including New York, passed laws making Labor Day a state holiday. Seven years later, President Grover Cleveland signed into law a measure establishing a Labor Day holiday for federal workers. 
 Labor Day caught on quickly among Gilded Age workers because, unlike the traditional forms of labor activism -- like striking and picketing, or civic holidays commemorating victories in war -- it drew together workers for the purposes of celebration. As P.J. McGuire later wrote of the parade: "No festival of martial glory of warrior's renown is this; no pageant pomp of warlike conquest.... It is a demonstration of fraternity and the harbinger of a better age, a more chivalrous time, when labor shall be best honored and well rewarded."
 In the 20th century, Labor Day parades grew into spectacles of pride and power. The high point came in 1961 when 200,000 workers marched up Fifth Avenue behind the grand marshal, Mayor Robert Wagner, passing reviewing stand dignitaries that included Gov. Nelson Rockefeller, Senator Jacob K. Javits and Harry S. Truman. But the strength of organized labor demonstrated by that parade was already being eroded by the emergence of the service economy, globalization and a political climate often hostile to unions. 
 By the late 1990's fewer than 15 percent of American workers belonged to unions, down from a peak of 39 percent, and Labor Day parades disappeared in many cities. Many that survived, like New York City's, were moved to the weekend after Labor Day so people could enjoy a final three-day summer weekend of recreation.
 Still, many concerns that inspired the first Labor Day persist. Public distrust of corporations has spiked in recent years as a result of scandals in accounting and campaign finance and huge payouts to departing executives. Polls indicate that more and more Americans are worried about job security, health care costs and pension funding. Whether it all ultimately leads Americans to "Strike With the Ballot" remains to be seen. In the meantime Labor Day will presumably endure, an annual reminder of battles won and battles yet to be joined.

HEADLINE: A French Roadblock to Free Trade 

 BODY:
French farmers and government officials are fond of saying that the word "culture" is contained within the term "agriculture" for a reason. Farming is a way of life, the French argue, which governments are entitled to protect from the impact of "mindless trade liberalization" in a way that they ought not protect, say, refrigerator manufacturers. The French have a strong attachment to the ideal of the bucolic countryside, and a change in agricultural policy can be blown up into a threat to national identity.
 Those attitudes are important because they make France the leading supporter of the European Union's costly protectionist agricultural policy, and the major opponent of any serious change. That intransigence hurts developing countries, where farmers often find themselves competing with the artificially low prices of subsidized European produce that gets dumped on the international market. 
 As members of the World Trade Organization meet in Cancun, Mexico, next month, they'll be trying to overcome French protectionism that threatens to stall momentum toward expanding global trade. Great Britain, the Netherlands and some Scandinavian countries tend to be more open to change -- something that is not surprising because they pay in more to the European farm support system than they take out. (American trade negotiators support reducing subsidies and trade barriers on agriculture -- though their sentiments are not always shared by the farm lobby in Congress.)
Europe's protectionism stems from the Continent's political determination to sustain agriculture even when it makes little economic sense. European farms are, on average, far smaller than those in the United States -- the European Union has more than three times as many farms even though it has only about one-third as much cultivated farmland. The idea of bigger farms frightens the French, just like the idea of depopulated farming communities. But it is possible to advance some of the more sensible goals of Europe's agriculture policy, like land conservation and environmentalism, without losing touch with reality. Europe loses about 3 percent of its farming population a year, and more consolidation, in the form of larger-scale farming and an abandonment of absurdly inefficient production, is inevitable. And while there is no question that Europe has a right, even an obligation, to spend money on rural development and the protection of open space, it is not sensible to believe that every village that was inhabited in Charlemagne's day must be sustained. Moreover, Europe's common agricultural policy in its present form does not always advance the humble family farmers often pointed to in its defense. Larger corporate agricultural interests get a disproportionate share of farm aid, giving Europeans who pay for the subsidies the worst of both worlds. And the current subsidies actually often hurt the environment by promoting overproduction.
A sensible compromise would provide government support for farmers who protect land from development and maintain high environmental standards. But it would not pay farmers to grow crops they couldn't sell under normal circumstances and dump the result on the global market, driving prices down too low for poor countries to make a profit on their own exports. The European Commission recently moved in that direction. It proposed reforms to the common agricultural policy that would stop linking farmers' subsidies to the amount they produce. But farmers across Europe hated the idea. "We don't want to get checks simply because we live somewhere remote and are nice people," said Franz-Josef Feiter, who heads the Committee of Agricultural Organizations in the European Union, the main farm lobby in Brussels. "Ours are industrialized societies with high wages and we must assure similarly good wages for our farmers." 
France led the fight against the commission's reform and, with the help of German allies, was able to water down the final deal announced in June. Now, on the eve of the W.T.O. gathering in Cancun, European and American trade officials are negotiating the details of a common approach to reducing their harmful restraints to trade in farm goods. If this effort is to succeed, France must come to terms with the fact that at the very least, the time has come to renounce the dumping of any subsidized farm products on world markets, and to open its domestic market to imports from poor nations, free of any tariffs or quotas.

Harvesting Poverty: Editorials in this series remain online at nytimes.com/harvestingpoverty.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Labor Day: Time for Pink Slips

BYLINE:  By HUBERT B. HERRING

 BODY:
 Labor Day means that employers are about to roll up their corporate sleeves and put the jobless masses back to work, right? On the contrary, alas. If history is a faithful guide, as it sometimes is, bosses are even now sharpening their knives. 
 For the past eight years, the September-to-December period has averaged 25 percent more job cuts a month than the rest of the year -- and 36 percent more than in the summer months -- according to a survey by the outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas. Why? Employers are putting finishing touches on the next year's budgets, meaning payrolls can suffer. So John A. Challenger, the firm's chief executive, has this advice: Don't slack off, especially now. You don't want to look expendable. HUBERT B. HERRING
